title: Trump’s Tariff Loophole Crackdown Cripples China’s Junk-Goods Pipeline
content: The Trump administration’s move to shut down a long-standing tariff loophole is already hammering Chinese exporters and disrupting e-commerce giants ...
resumen:
The Trump administration's move to shut down a long-standing tariff loophole is already hammering Chinese exporters and disrupting e-commerce giants.

New customs data show that the value of small packages shipped from China to the U.S. cratered to just over $1 billion in May, marking a 40% year-over-year drop and the lowest since early 2023.

The decline coincides with President Donald Trump’s April decision to end the so-called “de minimis” loophole, which allowed packages valued under $800 to enter the U.S. duty-free.

The policy change was unveiled as part of Trump’s “Liberation Day” tariff announcement.

The Trump administration said that China enforces strict import restrictions and tightly limits de minimis exemptions, showing no similar leniency toward U.S. shipments.

Chinese e-commerce platforms like Temu built their business models around the rule, shipping low-cost clothing, electronics and household goods directly to American consumers in small, duty-free packages.

Since Trump closed the exemption, those parcels are now subject to duties as high as 54%.

Temu’s weekly U.S. sales dropped more than 25% from mid-May to early June.

One Chinese business owner said that without the exemption, it would mean tougher business and much fewer options for consumers, and potentially higher prices.

Larry Severini, who owns a plant that produces the embroidery for American flags, said that the de minimis loophole was decimating their industry.

The Trump administration framed the closure of the de minimis loophole as a way to combat the flow of opioids, which killed over 76,000 Americans in 2023.

The administration said that President Trump is targeting deceptive shipping practices by Chinese-based shippers, many of whom hide illicit substances, including synthetic opioids, in low-value packages to exploit the de minimis exemption.

title: Trump’s tariff turbulence is reshaping Vietnam’s trade future
content: Hanoi must adapt swiftly to the new era of trade uncertainty if it is to remain competitive and continue to progress towards its development goals.
resumen: US President Donald Trump’s 46 per cent ‘reciprocal’ tariff on Vietnamese exports, initially intended to be effective from 9 April 2025, has been paused for 90 days. In 2023, exports constituted 87.2 per cent of Vietnam’s GDP. The United States imported US$136.6 billion of Vietnamese goods in 2024. Key sectors like electronics reached a US$123.5 billion trade surplus with the United States in 2024 — an 18.1 per cent annual increase. During Minister of Industry and Trade Nguyen Hong Dien’s March 2025 visit to Washington, Vietnam struck a US$4.15 billion energy deal with US firms. General Secretary To Lam’s swift congratulatory call with Trump after his election victory in April 2025. Hanoi offered to remove tariffs on US agricultural machinery, medical devices and Boeing aircraft. The 46 per cent tariff threatens to derail Vietnam’s 2025 8 per cent GDP growth target. With US exports to Vietnam totalling just US$13.1 billion in 2024. The Trump administration’s stated goal of generating US$600 billion annually from tariffs.

Trump-appointed Fed Governor Christopher Waller's recent comments that interest rates could be reduced in July.

Beijing is yet to sign the deal and the European Union remains quiet.

title: Trump floats cutting China tariffs to 80% ahead of meeting as he looks to deescalate trade war
content: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump on Friday floated cutting tariffs on China from 145% to 80% ahead of a weekend meeting among top U.S. and Chinese trade officials as he looks to deescalate ...
resumen: President Donald Trump floated cutting tariffs on China from 145% to 80% ahead of a weekend meeting as he looks to deescalate the trade war. Top U.S. officials are set to meet with a high-level Chinese delegation this weekend in Switzerland. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer will meet with their counterparts in Geneva. Trump wrote on his social media account on Friday morning, referring to Scott Bessent, his Treasury chief. The Republican president also called on China to open its markets to the U.S. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt clarified that such a potential move would not come "unilaterally" ahead of talks. Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer will meet with their counterparts in Geneva. The U.S. tariffs against China are now at 145% and China tariffs on the U.S. at 125%. Trump said he "could" lower the 145% rate charged on Chinese goods if the weekend talks go well.

title: The China Wild Card
content: Beijing is one of Tehran’s most important economic partners. But experts question how much China will help Iran if it retaliates against the United States.
resumen:
China’s ambassador to the United Nations, Fu Cong, has criticized the American strike on Iran.

After President Trump’s decision to bomb Iran’s nuclear facilities, there are questions.

The U.S.’s action might grant China greater leverage in its broader negotiations with Trump over trade and nearly everything else.

Scott Kennedy of the Center for Strategic and International Studies said: “The U.S.’s call for China to counsel Iran to not close the Strait of Hormuz adds to the list of things Washington needs from Beijing, the others being its rare earth exports, cracking down on the fentanyl trade, and reducing its trade surplus. As a result, China’s potential leverage grows and the costs to the U.S. from escalating in any domain against China grows.”

Bonnie Glaser, who runs the Indo-Pacific program at the German Marshall Fund explained: “Chinese interests are in a cease-fire, not a wider war. I don’t think the Chinese will support Iranian strikes on the U.S.”

Ryan Hass, a senior fellow and director at the Thornton China Center at the Brookings Institution, said: “China is much more important to Iran than vice versa.” About 90 percent of Iran’s oil exports go to China, but that represents just 10 percent of China’s oil imports.

Many Taiwanese were worried that if the U.S. didn’t stand by Israel, it might not come to Taipei’s aid, Glazer said. She added: “Now that the U.S. has conducted the strike, Taiwan will be somewhat reassured.”

Kennedy suggested that Xi “may find that Trump’s unpredictability raises the risks over being more aggressive on Taiwan, but if the U.S. quickly backs down and doesn’t develop a clear overall strategy, Xi might sense greater room for maneuver.”

The upper chamber’s parliamentarian, Elizabeth MacDonough, rejected a provision that would have limited lawsuits seeking to block President Trump’s executive orders; she already rebuffed an effort to push some of the costs of food aid programs onto states.

Tesla begins testing its Robotaxis in Austin.

Bank of New York Mellon approaches Northern Trust about a merger.

Jay Powell, the central bank’s chair, is set to testify before Congress on Tuesday and Wednesday.

The price of Brent crude came down to about $76 on Monday morning after having opened above $81 in Asia.

Trump administration officials conceded that the state of Iran’s nuclear program remained unclear, with the fate of the country’s near-weapons-grade uranium still unknown.

Iranian state media reported that the country’s parliament is weighing whether to suspend cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency.

Israel and Iran are continuing to exchange rocket fire, with explosions taking place in southern Israel and in Tehran.

Roughly one fifth of global oil products pass through the waterway, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration. In 2024, that amounted to an average of 20 million barrels of oil each day.

Joachim Klement, an analyst at Panmure Liberum, estimated that a total shutdown of the strait could cause stock markets to drop as much as 20 percent.

Saudi Arabia is the biggest exporter relying on the strait, accounting for nearly 40 percent of the oil exports that moved through there last year. Saudi Aramco, the kingdom’s national oil company, would likely take a hit.

Iraq is the second biggest exporter, followed by the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait and Iran itself.

China is the top destination for oil transported through the strait.

Jason Miller, a professor of supply chain management at Michigan State University, said: “Iran closing that strait is a very negative ramification for China.” Chinese oil refiners would be among the most affected companies in that country, Miller said.

More than 80 percent of oil exports through the strait end up in Asian markets, according to the E.I.A. Besides China, other top destinations are India, South Korea and Japan.

Higher energy costs would affect everyone, including the U.S.

Miller said: “We’ve got uncertainty about tariffs and tariff policy. Now, we’re adding uncertainty about energy prices to the mix, because we don’t know what Iran will decide to do.”

Some shipowners have already paused transits in the Strait of Hormuz because of mounting security concerns, Jakob Larsen, chief safety and security officer at BIMCO, an international shipping association, told DealBook.

Eugene Gholz, a professor of political science at the University of Notre Dame, told DealBook: Any individual company that ships through the strait would be impacted, though the energy industry is the key concern.

Fu Cong, China’s ambassador to the United Nations, told China’s state broadcaster on Sunday: “Iran is harmed, but also harmed is U.S. credibility — as a country and as a party to any international negotiations.”

Russia, a longtime ally of Iran, condemned the attack, though President Vladimir Putin hasn’t issued a public statement. Tehran’s foreign minister has gone to Moscow to ask for help.

Saudi Arabia’s foreign ministry called for de-escalation and a political solution, but stopped short of condemning the U.S., as it had Israel when that country launched strikes earlier in the month.

European officials — including Kaja Kallas, the European Union’s top diplomat; President Emmanuel Macron of France; and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain — also called for de-escalation.

Seven B-2 Spirit stealth bombers were used to carry out the mission, flying from their home base in Missouri, according to Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. They cost about $2.1 billion each.

Fourteen GBU-57 A/B bombs were dropped on the Natanz and Fordo enrichment sites, Caine said.

More than two dozen Tomahawk missiles were fired at the Iranian facility at Isfahan from a Navy submarine. They cost about $2 million each.

Fred Smith, who turned a Yale college paper into FedEx, the global shipping giant, and amassed a billion-dollar fortune and political influence, died on Saturday. He was 80.

Smith’s greatest innovation was a hub-and-spoke system of routes. He based the sorting of packages in Memphis, where he found an unused airplane hangar. He flew his planes at night, when the skies were relatively empty.

Smith changed the corporate name from Federal Express to FedEx and embarked on ground shipping, which put FedEx in competition with itself but gave customers a more affordable option.

Prosus, the big European-based tech investor, said its annual earnings jumped 47 percent year-on-year and that it was confident its $4.7 billion takeover of Just Eat Takeaway.com would win regulatory approval.

title: JLR faces £1.6bn tariff blow in its US export market
content: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is preparing for a potential £1.6 billion hit in the wake of newly imposed US tariffs.
resumen:
Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is preparing for a potential £1.6 billion hit in the wake of newly imposed US tariffs.

The impact of these tariffs, introduced under US President Donald Trump’s administration, was confirmed by Tata Group chairman N Chandrasekaran at the company’s annual meeting on June 20.

Without intervention, JLR's tariff rate for exports to the US would have jumped from 2-2.5% to a punishing 27.5%.

However, thanks to a recent UK-US trade agreement signed in May, tariffs will now be capped at 10% - translating into an estimated £1.6 billion cost impact.

Even so, JLR, which derives over a quarter of its global sales from the US, said it is implementing mitigation measures to reduce the net impact to around £600 million.

It has forecast lower earnings for FY26, with operating margins expected to fall from 10% to between 5% and 7%.

Shares in JLR owner Tata Motors dropped 5.2% in early trading following the news, reported The Financial Express.

The company initially suspended shipments to the US following the introduction of the 25% blanket tariff on all foreign-made vehicles and said it was rerouting available stock to more accessible markets while it evaluates pricing strategies to absorb the increased costs.

Despite the pressure, JLR’s recent performance has been robust. Revenues reached £28.9 billion, with an EBIT margin of 8.5% and a pre-tax profit of £2.5 billion.

Chandrasekaran credited the ongoing success of the Range Rover and Defender franchises, as well as the local CKD (Completely Knocked Down) assembly of some models in India, for supporting growth.

The UK-built Range Rover line remains a cornerstone of the JLR brand, although the Defender, produced in Slovakia, is more vulnerable to US trade policy.

Slovakia, as part of the EU, will not benefit from the UK-specific trade deal, making those vehicles potentially subject to the full 25% tariff.

JLR said it is in ongoing talks with both the US and UK governments to navigate trade policy in a bid to minimise disruption.

title: Economía en tiempo de guerra (OPINION)
content: Desde que inició la administración Abinader a regentar el Estado Dominicano, esta se ha caracterizado en mejorar la calidad de vida de los dominicanos, haciendo hincapié en: alimentación, vivienda, sa ...
resumen:
Desde que inició la administración Abinader a regentar el Estado Dominicano, esta se ha caracterizado en mejorar la calidad de vida de los dominicanos, haciendo hincapié en: alimentación, vivienda, salud, educación y en reactivar la economía y las finanzas públicas de la nación dominicana.

Dicha gestión se enfrentó en 2020 a la pandemia Covid-19, una guerra sin enemigos visibles, pero también con una economía y finanzas disminuidas por la mala administración de la cosa pública de parte de las autoridades anteriores a las gestiones del gobierno de los últimos casi 5 años.

Ha sido una gestión de gobierno enfrentando: amenazas, retos y debilidades, heredadas del pasado y, como si fuera poco con los efectos de las crisis de los mercados financieros externos, problemas de inflación importada, originada por la guerra Rusia-Ucrania, provocando desabastecimiento de los principales commodities, bienes e insumos para la producción.

Todos estos acontecimientos llevaron al gobierno que preside el presidente Abinader, ser creativo, resiliente, a mostrar valentía en la toma de decisiones oportunas y adecuadas, conforme el vaivén o a tono con los eventos económicos y financieros globales.

Se tomaron decisiones monetarias y fiscales para evitar que la economía y las finanzas locales se fueran a pique o a la ruina, medidas que surtieron los efectos esperados a pesar de los sacrificios por los cuales se vio sometida la nación dominicana pero a pesar de ello, los frutos positivos fueron los esperados.

Tales como el turismo recuperado, economía reactivada, finanzas disciplinadas, crecimiento macroeconómico igual o casi al potencial de la economía dominicana.

Estabilidad de la tasa de cambio, aumento de las inversiones extranjeras directas, aumento de visitantes al país, incremento de las exportaciones dominicanas, aumento de las remesas, en fin una economía en pleno apogeo, a pesar de las vicisitudes que tuvo que enfrentar desde sus inicios la administración Abinader.

Estos aspectos que han caracterizado la gestión de las actuales autoridades no han cesado totalmente, en lugar de ello se han recrecido, pues no ha pasado un día que los retos y amenazas económicas, comerciales y financieras no se presenten con nuevas características, afectando los cimientos mismos de la economía dominicana y global.

Con la asunción del presidente Donald Trump a la presidencia de los Estados Unidos de Norteamérica, el mundo ha vivido una serie de amenazas, afectando la economía y finanzas de los países, debido a los aumentos de los aranceles.

Así también, al incrementarse y extenderse las acciones bélicas entre países que no estaban participando en las luchas de intereses económicos, geopolíticos y religiosos, que originalmente iniciaron las conflagraciones, que por gran tiempo componían el escenario de la repartición del mundo y la lucha por el Litio, Tierra Negra y Petróleo.

Toda acción guerrera o de índole económica, afecta al país como también a todas las naciones en este mundo interconectado, un mundo globalizado, sin fronteras, sin límites.

El país y el mundo se enfrentan a una nueva amenaza como es el hecho del incremento de las acciones bélicas, además de Israel y Palestina (Hamas), Rusia y Ucrania, Israel, Irán y Estados Unidos.

Ahora se complica con la participación del país del norte de América, con posibilidad de que intervengan otras naciones, como la India, Paquistán, China y Rusia.

Recrudecimiento bélico que pudiese llevar al mundo al borde de una guerra mundial, con consecuencias impredecibles, afectando las estructuras mismas de las naciones.

En los últimos días, la máxima autoridad del Banco Central de la República Dominicana (Junta Monetaria), decidió tomar medidas de estímulos monetarios para continuar activando la economía.

La entidad emisora dominicana, decidió liberar unos RD$81 mil millones del encaje legal a favor de sectores productivos, los cuales podrían tener un impacto positivo en la economía dominicana en el mediano plazo.

La efectividad de esta medida dependerá de la correcta canalización de los RD$81 mil millones y, de la superación de barreras estructurales, como la informalidad empresarial, situación financiera, como la escasez de mano de obra, con lo cual se garantiza el aumento del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB).

Las expectativas de crecimiento del PIB han sido revisadas hacia la baja debido a la incertidumbre comercial que impera en el mundo, el bajo crecimiento económico de Estados Unidos, incremento de la inflación de dicho país.

A lo interno, debido a las bajas recaudaciones que caracterizaron los primeros meses del año como consecuencia del palpitar económico que hoy afecta al mundo.

Las autoridades monetarias y fiscales han tenido un excelente desempeño en el manejo de sus acciones, comprendidos en sus ámbitos, no menos cierto que las variables exógenas e incontrolables, que a cada momento afectan a la nación dominicana han dado lugar a que se tenga que ajustar la economía a cada momento.

Hoy el mundo se enfrenta a un nuevo escenario, un horizonte de guerra que podría incrementarse, lo que obligaría a las autoridades monetarias y financieras del país a recomponer las fichas del parché o el ajedrez.

Dicha situación impondría mayor cautela en el gasto, en el manejo de la economía en general del país.

Al vivir en modo de economía de guerra, el país debe reorganizar su industria para asegurar que su capacidad de producción esté configurada de manera óptima.

Al vivir en un ambiente de guerra regularmente se reduce el crecimiento, la guerra aumenta la inflación.

Los precios de los combustibles y los alimentos suben con rapidez, afectando especialmente a los segmentos poblacionales más vulnerables, sobre todo a los países de bajos ingresos.

Surgiría más incertidumbre cambiaria, afectaría la política fiscal instrumentada, debilidad en los mercados internos, aumento del desempleo, bajaría la demanda y la producción.

Inseguridad pública, aumento de precios de insumos y materias primas.

En caso de una guerra mundial, el PIB per cápita disminuiría, debido a una menor productividad laboral y total de los factores de la producción, por la destrucción del capital físico y humano existente.

La falta de inversión de nuevo capital físico y humano, debido a la reducción de las ganancias provenientes del comercio interno y externo.

Los rasgos de un modo a otro, no siempre se dan totales o no siempre afectan por igual a todas las naciones sino que, estos eventos pueden afectar negativamente a muchos países mientras a otros los puede favorecer, al no estar en la línea del frente guerrero directamente.

Como las autoridades gubernamentales dominicanas actuales, han demostrado desde los inicios de sus ejecutorias, ser proactivas, eficientes, efectivas y resilientes, no hay dudas que desde ya toman las medidas precautorias para evitar males mayores debido a los efectos de los últimos acontecimientos comerciales y de guerra.

title: Lidan Qi Zhou, de Puente China: "España y China están en su luna de miel, es momento de consolidar relaciones con Cataluña"
content: La consejera delegada de la consultora especializada en las relaciones bilaterales ofrece varios puntos clave sobre la inversión asiática en la región, como la inmobiliaria, la sanitaria o la gastronó ...
resumen:
Lidan Qi Zhou, consejera delegada de Puente China, afirma que "España y China están en su luna de miel, es momento de consolidar relaciones con Cataluña". Puente China, consultora especializada en relaciones bilaterales, tiene su sede en Barcelona y recibe delegaciones asiáticas interesadas en invertir en España. La consultora ha reforzado relaciones comerciales, industriales y de amistad entre China y España durante casi tres décadas. Qi Zhou destaca la importancia de esta amistad para un nuevo horizonte económico. En los años 90, Puente China atrajo inversores chinos al sector inmobiliario catalán, y actualmente se enfocan en inversión tecnológica, sanitaria y gastronómica.

Lidan Qi Zhou y su hermana Liling Qi Zhou (presidenta del grupo) llegaron a España en los años 80 y 89 respectivamente, comenzando con un negocio familiar de hostelería. Posteriormente, importaron mecheros y relojes de China. Con las Olimpiadas del 92, se mudaron a Barcelona y se adentraron en el mercado inmobiliario.

China considera el sector inmobiliario como un valor seguro. Puente China acompaña a los inversores chinos en todo el proceso, desde la selección de propiedades hasta la gestión de la compra. La burocracia bancaria española, especialmente el control de divisas, es un desafío para los inversores. Históricamente, los inversores chinos se han interesado en viviendas, pero ahora también se orientan hacia proyectos industriales, urbanísticos y hoteleros.

La Golden Visa, que dejó de funcionar en abril de 2024, ha afectado a la inversión china, especialmente para quienes buscan comprar una casa y vivir en España.

En 2020, Puente China gestionó la compra de 1,9 millones de mascarillas para el Govern catalán por 931.000 euros. La empresa donó mascarillas a China al inicio de la pandemia y gestionó la entrega de material desde China a España, aprovechando sus relaciones establecidas durante más de 20 años.

Puente China tiene una pata de innovación con ingeniería propia, incluyendo software y hardware, como una caja inteligente para gestionar el stock de hospitales. Su objetivo es introducir tecnología china en los hospitales españoles y servicios españoles en China.

Qi Zhou opina que la relación entre China y España está en su "luna de miel" y es el momento de consolidar las relaciones entre China, España y Cataluña. Considera que es importante tejer alianzas estratégicas y que el presidente Salvador Illa será bien recibido en China.

Puente China ayuda a empresas españolas a entrar en el mercado chino y son socios de Enrique Tomás en China, con cuatro tiendas abiertas en el aeropuerto de Shenzhen. La empresa está introduciendo la gastronomía española en hoteles y supermercados chinos.

Qi Zhou considera que es importante la ampliación del aeropuerto de El Prat y la conexión con ciudades como Cantón y Xi'an.

El próximo año, Puente China cumplirá su 30 aniversario y su objetivo es mostrar una China verdadera a nivel cultural, social y económico, y dar a conocer Cataluña y España. La empresa impulsa el intercambio de estudiantes a través de la Fundación Puente China.
tags: ['inversión extranjera', 'relaciones internacionales', 'economía global', 'inversión en infraestructura', 'desarrollo económico']

title: La peligrosa seducción del victimismo en la política
content: Atribuir la culpa a "otros" es una táctica política tentadora para ganar apoyo. Sin embargo, esta estrategia de victimismo a menudo empeora las cosas y daña a quienes busca proteger.
resumen:
El artículo trata sobre la estrategia política de atribuir la culpa a "otros" para ganar apoyo, conocida como victimismo.

Esta estrategia, aunque tentadora, a menudo empeora las cosas y daña a quienes busca proteger.

Se mencionan ejemplos como:

*   Políticos locales en ciudades indias que proponen cuotas de empleo para nativos, argumentando que los migrantes obtienen los mejores trabajos.
*   Políticos en Estados Unidos que aseguran que los estudiantes nativos meritorios no logran entrar a las mejores universidades.
*   La propuesta de la administración Trump de aplicar aranceles a la importación de iPhones para repatriar su fabricación.

Se argumenta que estas políticas pueden tener consecuencias negativas, como:

*   Disminución de la productividad y competitividad de las empresas.
*   Reducción de la calidad del alumnado en las universidades.
*   Aumento de los precios de los productos.

Se contrasta con el ejemplo de Singapur, donde un ministro defendió la atracción de estudiantes chinos, argumentando la necesidad de ser competitivos a nivel mundial.

Se concluye que, en lugar de culpar a otros, es mejor enfocarse en mejorar las capacidades y oportunidades de los rezagados.

El autor es Raghuram G. Rajan, ex gobernador del Banco de Reserva de la India y ex economista principal del Fondo Monetario Internacional.

title: EEUU metido en una guerra que acelera su agresiva caída imperial
content: Rusia ha salido fortalecida de esa contienda, mientras Europa Occidental y EEUU han quedado bastante debilitados.
resumen: El mundo unipolar quedó atrás con la emergencia de China y de Rusia como superpotencias, los avances económicos de la India, la transformación espectacular de Irán, la formación y ampliación de los BRICs y la reactivación de los procesos de autodeterminación en África, Asia y Nuestra América. Al avanzar el siglo XXI estamos viviendo un violento tránsito, todavía inconcluso y no institucionalizado, del mundo unipolar a un mundo multipolar en el que crece la demanda de respeto de las diversas soberanías. Ese tránsito ha sido posible por el inicio del proceso de decadencia y el despliegue de la indetenible crisis de la civilización occidental. Más recientemente se está produciendo una aceleración de la decadencia y descomposición de EEUU y del imperialismo occidental. Ese declive se ha profundizado y está entrando en una fase de derrumbe del poderío hegemónico estadounidense, de sucesivas derrotas y recurrentes fracasos de sus apasionados esfuerzos y sus despliegues de guerras y sus variadas modalidades de violencia dirigidas a retener zonas conquistadas, recuperar terreno perdido, desintegrar fuerzas adversas y detener su caída progresiva. EE.UU, las potencias europeas y OTAN perdieron la guerra contra las Federación Rusa, en el escenario ucraniano y han fracasado nuevamente en su viejo y pérfido sueño de desintegrarla y apoderarse de su inmenso territorio y enormes riquezas. Rusia ha salido fortalecida de esa contienda, mientras Europa Occidental y EEUU han quedado bastante debilitados. A su vez, en este periodo, China ha conquista el sitial de primera potencia tecnológica y comercial del planeta y obliga a EEUU a recular es su guerra de aranceles. Israel, instrumento de EEUU en el Medio Oriente, no ha podido vencer la heroica resistencia palestina e islámica, ni mucho menos tener éxito en la reciente y cruel aventura que le asignó el PENTÁGONO estadounidense, de atacar, destruir y vencer a Irán. Los mata-niños sionistas han encontrado su tumba en su vecina Irán, luego de atreverse a bombardearla. La respuesta iraní ha sido demoledora, al punto que Netanyhau ha tenido que pedir auxilio y solicitarle a Trump involucrar directamente a EEUU en la guerra. El trumpismo, la cúpula globalista y la alta jerarquía del PENTÁGONO, dominada desde los tiempos de BUSH padre por la idea de recuperar por la fuerza la hegemonía absoluta y el dominio del Planeta. El establishment político y empresarial de Gringolandia es profundamente sionista y pro sionista. Las élites del PD y el PR son pro-sionistas. El lobby judeo-sionista es extremadamente influyente en WALL STREET, en los omnipotentes bancos de negocio y en el complejo militar –industrial- financiero. Actualmente el sionismo domina el Congreso y pesa mucho en la Casa Blanca. Ni Trump ni ningún presidente de EEUU tiene fuerza propia para zafarse de esos amarres, porque desobedecer esas directrices desata fuerzas poderosas fuera de control. EEUU se acaba de meter en una guerra de la que le será difícil salir sin recibir una gran y definitiva derrota. Su primera incursión ha fracasado según informaciones contundente de Rusia e Irán que aseguras que el escudo subterráneo que protege las estaciones nucleares israelí no ha sido afectado por los bombardeos norteamericanos. Trump y el Pentágono han fracasado y continúan perdiendo respaldo del pueblo estadounidense. ¡Hasta pro-sionistas como Obama y Clinton, en descarada actitud oportunista con escasa credibilidad, arremeten contra Trump! EEUU pierde cada vez más el apoyo mundial y tiende a convertirse en Súper-Estado paria, muy aislado. Irán tiene aliados poderosos y diversos en el mundo islámico y en todo el mundo. Arabia Saudita, Qaatar y Pakistán la están apoyando. El parlamento iraní decidió bloquear el estrecho de ORMUZ y su mando militar ha implementado una nueva ofensiva devastadora contra Israel. Palestina tiene un apoyo mundial impresionante. Ni Irán, ni Palestina, ni Rusia, ni China, ni Cuba, ni Venezuela, ni Nicaragua, ni los BRICs ni los pueblos en lucha por su autodeterminación, están solos…todos confluyen y van conformando un torrente o gran bloque incontenible hacia un mundo multipolar y un nuevo orden mundial.

title: A war markets weren’t ready for: what US strikes on Iran mean for the global economy
content: US airstrikes on Iran raise fears of an oil supply shock and global inflation spike. Here’s what Trump’s latest move means for energy markets, interest rates, and global growth.
resumen:
The United States bombed Iran’s nuclear enrichment sites. Oil markets reacted sharply, with crude jumping 8.8% and fears of $130 oil if Hormuz is disrupted. The US remains insulated, while Europe, China, and oil importers face serious exposure to rising prices.

The airstrikes were targeted and precise. Trump hit three nuclear sites in Iran, after giving Israel space to weaken Tehran’s long-range missile capability. Iranian leaders have already made threats that they will retaliate. Iran’s economy is fragile enough to not be able to sustain a prolonged conflict with both the US and Israel. From the US side, there are no signs of a full-scale invasion or deployment of American troops so far. The majority of Americans oppose a war with Iran.

The Strait of Hormuz, a 21-mile-wide channel, carries 20% of the world’s daily oil supply and a massive chunk of liquefied natural gas. Iran has repeatedly threatened to close it even before the US attacks. Bloomberg Economics forecasts that a full shutdown of Hormuz would send oil past $130 per barrel. That could drive US inflation back to 4% and likely force the Federal Reserve to delay or cancel expected rate cuts. It would also crush growth in countries like Germany, Japan, India, and China, who are heavily exposed to energy imports. After the strikes, crude oil derivatives jumped 8.8%.

The US economy is better positioned than most. After the shale boom, America became a near-balanced oil trader, exporting and importing roughly the same amount. Russia could benefit from the chaos. China is now in a bind. Nearly all of Iran’s oil exports go to Beijing, and China has enjoyed steep discounts of around $6 per barrel cheaper than market prices. Europe is exposed too. If Qatar’s LNG exports are disrupted, which also flow through Hormuz, European gas prices could spike, especially in winter.

Saudi Arabia operates a 5 million barrel-per-day pipeline from its Gulf fields to the Red Sea. The UAE has a 1.5 million barrel-per-day line to Fujairah, bypassing Hormuz. Iraq, Kuwait, and Qatar, all 3 who are key exporters, have no viable alternatives.

There are three likely paths from here. In the most limited case, Iran retaliates with minor attacks on US bases or assets, and the conflict stays contained. Oil rises moderately, inflation ticks up, but central banks stay the course. In a mid-range scenario, Iran targets Gulf infrastructure or commercial tankers. The Strait of Hormuz becomes semi-operational. Oil spikes into the $110–$120 range. The Fed, ECB, and others freeze rate cuts, while global growth stalls. In the worst case, Hormuz shuts down entirely. Crude surges past $130. Inflation hits 4–5%. Interest rates stay high through 2025. Europe and Asia face energy crises. China scrambles to source oil at higher prices. Russia benefits. Markets spiral.

title: Por qué los bonos apuntan a ser el gran negocio para los inversores de cara al segundo semestre

Según el Gurú de la City, comprar bonos en pesos a tasas superiores al 30% anual se presenta como un gran negocio.

El mundo podría no crecer a un ritmo superior al 3,0% anual.

El euro en 1,16 por dólar sigue aumentando.

El 9 de julio será una fecha clave, se definirán los aranceles comerciales de Estados Unidos con el mundo.

El 24 de junio el índice MSCI (Morgan Stanley Capital International) realiza su revisión anual de clasificación de mercados, y Argentina podría ser reclasificada.

El mercado argentino alcanzó un máximo en enero del año 2025 tocando el índice Merval los u$s2.400, luego hizo pie en los u$s1.400 y hoy cotiza en u$s1.783.

El Banco Central mantiene reservas por encima de los u$s40.000 millones.

El Banco Central tiene una base monetaria de $36 billones, de los cuales $22,5 billones es dinero en circulación.

La tesorería tiene en el Banco Central depositado un total de $16,8 billones.

El dólar mayorista el viernes cerró en $1.156,17, en el mes de junio este dólar cae el 3,3%.

La inflación esperada para los primeros 6 meses se ubicaría en el 15%.

title: Radiografía de los consumidores argentinos: 3 de cada 10 gastan más de lo que ganan y el 40% no puede ahorrar
content: Argentina 23/06/2025.- Las decisiones financieras cotidianas se volvieron una tarea estratégica en sí misma. Entre promociones, recortes, angustias emocionales y aspiraciones de estabilidad, la econom ...
resumen: En Argentina, tres de cada diez personas gastan más de lo que ganan y el 40% no puede ahorrar. Solo el 28% de la población logra guardar dinero, un porcentaje inferior al de países vecinos como Brasil, México y Colombia. El informe “Argentina, ¿cómo estás?” elaborado por Quiddity en el marco del Monitor Anual de Humor Social 2025 presenta datos que exponen una economía personal tensionada. El 30% de la población gasta más de lo que ingresa y el 40% no logra ahorrar nada mes a mes. En 2025, se prioriza recuperar productos resignados, como carnes y lácteos, y mantener ciertos gustos esenciales. El 42% de los argentinos elige viajar en temporada baja, el 27% planifica con antelación, y el 24% selecciona el transporte más económico. El 28% aprovecha actividades gratuitas en el destino. Los sectores de nivel socioeconómico (NSE) alto lideran la reactivación, mientras los NSE bajos destinan el 32% de su gasto a alimentos y bebidas. El 91% de las categorías creció gracias a descuentos, y el volumen vendido con promociones aumentó un 110% con relación al año anterior. El 69% de los encuestados del Monitor Anual de Humor Social 2025 mantiene expectativas de mejora para este año. El 85% quiere sostener a su familia y ahorrar. El 20% considera a la inflación como el principal problema. El 42% de los argentinos considera a la inseguridad como el problema más grave del país. El 42% de los argentinos declara sentirse ansioso o preocupado, y el 40% se reconoce agotado. El 90% de los trabajadores del país manifiestan síntomas de estrés, y más de una cuarta parte vincula esta sensación con la situación económica. El 88% de los argentinos admite darse un gusto para levantar el ánimo, aunque solo el 21% logra ahorrar. El valor del metro cuadrado en Buenos Aires subió 2% en dólares nominales pero cayó 11% en pesos ajustados por inflación. El 80% de los argentinos ha escuchado sobre los aranceles que el gobierno de Donald Trump impuso a productos de China y Europa. El 70% cree que esas medidas impactarán negativamente en la economía argentina, y el 50% considera que una eventual reelección de Trump empeorará el panorama local. El 73% de los argentinos afirma que es difícil hablar de política sin entrar en conflicto.

resumen: Estados Unidos y México han llegado a un acuerdo que beneficiará a ambos países. La presidenta mexicana, Claudia Sheinbaum, anunció el acuerdo tras una conversación con Donald Trump. El diálogo entre ambos presidentes abre la puerta a un cambio importante. El acuerdo busca un pacto global que contemple seguridad, migración y comercio. La conversación telefónica entre Sheinbaum y Trump se produjo después de que una reunión en la Cumbre del G7 no pudiera concretarse. title: Can China build on eased trade tensions with US amid Trump’s many distractions?
content: Momentum may stall after London talks, but Beijing should advance a steady, leader-driven process, observers say.
resumen:
Mientras que las conversaciones entre Estados Unidos y China en Londres a principios de este mes sugirieron que Beijing tenía la ventaja negociadora sobre los otros principales socios comerciales de Washington, los observadores advierten que China puede necesitar moderar las expectativas de una restauración de los intercambios de alto nivel.

Las prioridades contrapuestas del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump, tanto a nivel nacional como internacional, podrían distraer a su administración de la necesidad apremiante de establecer un acuerdo duradero sobre las relaciones comerciales entre Estados Unidos y China, dijeron.

Pero si bien la administración Trump se encuentra en las primeras etapas de la formulación de su política hacia China, Beijing debería avanzar en un proceso liderado por líderes para estabilizar los lazos bilaterales, sentando las bases para un acuerdo comercial antes de una posible cumbre.

Sourabh Gupta, especialista en políticas senior del Instituto de Estudios China-América en Washington, dijo que el marco alcanzado en Londres fue "una genuina desescalada de las tensiones comerciales".

"Al menos, así es como las dos partes lo imaginan", dijo, señalando que el marco esencialmente marcó un regreso al acuerdo de Ginebra del mes pasado, con ambas partes teniendo "un interés personal en llegar a un 'sí' en un acuerdo comercial".

Según Gupta, el resultado de las conversaciones, junto con la primera llamada entre el presidente chino Xi Jinping y Trump desde que este último comenzó su segundo mandato, ha colocado a China como "líder" en las negociaciones de Washington con los principales socios comerciales.

Si bien el marco de Londres representa una tregua temporal en lugar de un acuerdo integral, ningún otro socio comercial de Estados Unidos ha asegurado un acuerdo comparable, a pesar de las negociaciones paralelas con la Unión Europea, Japón, Corea del Sur, Canadá, India y otros.

title: Old allies, new agenda
content: — Future allies: The partnership opens the door for Canada to negotiate a bilateral agreement that could eventually allow Ottawa to bid on joint EU defense procurements. A working dinner and ...
resumen:
Prime Minister MARK CARNEY started his morning at a military cemetery in northern Belgium.

Foreign Affairs Minister ANITA ANAND and Defense Minister DAVID MCGUINTY will join Carney to sign the EU-Canada Security and Defense Partnership Agreement.

The agreement outlines new collaboration on crisis management, cyber and hybrid threats, military mobility, maritime security and defense industrial cooperation.

The May 27 throne speech read by KING CHARLES III in the Senate stated, “The world is a more dangerous and uncertain place than at any point since the Second World War.”

Carney is meeting with European Commission President URSULA VON DER LEYEN and European Council President ANTÓNIO COSTA at the Canada-EU summit in Brussels.

Canada is approaching the summit as an opportunity to pivot towards a much closer relationship with the European Union as part of the diversification of economic and diplomatic relations.

The partnership opens the door for Canada to negotiate a bilateral agreement that could eventually allow Ottawa to bid on joint EU defense procurements.

The same Canadian official called it “the first step for Canada to participate in the ReArm Europe security action” noting that it provides up to 150 billion euros in EU loans to help EU member states increase their expenditure on common defense procurement.

Canada-U.S. Trade Minister DOMINIC LEBLANC says conversations between Ottawa and D.C. are focused — motivated by “the fact that there’s now a deadline set by the two leaders.”

The PM has asked KIRSTEN HILLMAN to stay on as Canada’s ambassador to Washington and play chief negotiator in the trade and security talks with the Trump administration.

President DONALD TRUMP and the PM started the clock at the G7 in Kananaskis — 30 days or bust.

Carney wants a deal to wipe out Trump’s tariffs — an “existential crisis” — and move on to other priorities in the “hinge moment” he keeps talking about.

POLITICO’s MEGAN MESSERLY tells us that with so many trade deadlines on the horizon, Canada is simply not a top priority.

A White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, tells Messerly the 30-day blitz was “a leader to leader thing” driven by Carney’s team.

On Tuesday, Carney makes way for the NATO leaders’ summit where he’ll briefly bask in the success of committing to the 2 percent-of-GDP target.

NATO allies have reached a deal on a new spending target of 5 percent of gross domestic product.

The new benchmark will split into a 3.5 percent contribution for military spending and 1.5 for spending in industry and infrastructure projects.

Trump said Friday he supports allies spending more but added the 5 percent target shouldn’t apply to the U.S., which is at 3.4 percent.

The cybersecurity industry is eyeing that 1.5 percent slice, hoping to profit on things like infrastructure and cybersecurity.

A Canadian official said that the investment that Canada is already making in infrastructure, in resilience, in everything that’s required in order for the defense to be delivered, would already take us through and past the 1.5 percent metric.

The G7 summit was roiled by claims that Trump wanted to “water down”. a declaration on Ukraine.

A Canadian official was asked during a Saturday briefing for reporters if the NATO statement will name Russia as a “threat” to the alliance.

A Canadian official said, “There are a very substantial number of allies, including Canada, that are very strongly of the view that Russia ought to be identified as a threat.”

The statement will express solidarity with Ukraine and underscore the importance of Ukraine security to transatlantic security.”

The Senate resumes sitting Wednesday when it will get the next chance to approve the government’s bill on internal trade, labor mobility and building big projects.

The House of Commons passed the sweeping “nation-building” bill Friday with Conservative support, and looks on track to become law by Canada Day, as the PM has pledged.

Carney said he will hold working sessions and public roundtables with First Nations leaders on July 17 with Inuit and Métis rights-holders, leadership and experts.

He also announced additional funding to help First Nations, Inuit and Métis participate.

Carney wants everyone to remember the underlying reason for all of this is U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

The PM is in Brussels. At 5 p.m. local time, he’s scheduled to arrive at the Canada-European Union Summit.

At 1 p.m. Ontario Deputy Premier SYLVIA JONES will hold a presser with JANE PHILPOTT, chair of the Primary Care Action Team.

JOHN MCCALLUM, (1950-2025) — Remembrances flowed in for the former Liberal Cabinet minister, and former ambassador to China, who died Saturday at age 75.

As an MP, McCallum served in numerous portfolios, including defense, veterans affairs and national revenue.

Before entering politics, he was dean of arts at McGill University and the chief economist for Royal Bank of Canada.

His most revered political accomplishment was burning the midnight oil at the immigration department to help make good on a 2015 Liberal campaign promise to bring almost 45,000 Syrian refugees to Canada.

Prime Minister MARK CARNEY called McCallum an inspiration, mentor and a friend.

Former Prime Minister JUSTIN TRUDEAU fondly recalled the Syrian refugee resettlement saying, McCallum “made it happen despite real challenges in an unpredictable time.”

Foreign Affairs Minister ANITA ANAND expressed gratitude for his “generosity, warmth and wisdom.”.

Birthdays: LAUREEN HARPER; JUDY FOOTE, Newfoundland and Labrador’s 14th and first female lieutenant governor; Conservative MP KELLY MCCAULEY and DAN PUJDAK of Blackbird Strategies.

Spotted: Tributes in the Senate last week to Sen. JUDITH G. SEIDMAN, who retires Sept. 1.

Movers and shakers: Just before the votes on Bill C-5, the PM announced the changes in the senior public service, noting: “A stronger Canada depends on a strong and effective public service – one that is focused on execution, delivery, and impact.”

JEAN-FRANÇOIS TREMBLAY becomes “senior official” at the Privy Council Office.

MOLLIE JOHNSON will take over as deputy minister of environment and climate change.

NANCY HAMZAWI was named president of the Public Health Agency of Canada.

ALISON O’LEARY will be associate deputy minister of finance.

Fisheries and Oceans Associate Deputy Minister KAILI LEVESQUE has been enlisted to support the secretary of state of nature.

title: Fresh food exporter Peloris sees NZ-China opportunities as US trade tension mounts
content: Peloris Group, which specialises in exporting fresh food to China, says opportunities are opening up for New Zealand and Australian producers while Sino-US trade relations remain strained. Co-founder ...
resumen: Peloris Group, which specializes in exporting fresh food to China, sees opportunities for New Zealand and Australian producers while Sino-US trade relations remain strained. Co-founder Peter Verry says if Australia and New Zealand producers can meet China’s quality and supply standards, then they could benefit from the trade rift between the world’s two biggest economies. Peloris pioneered fresh exports of Australian and New Zealand food to China in 2014. Peloris pioneered fresh milk exports to China a decade ago. Peloris has an officially credited 12-hour clearance lane in China. Finely honed logistics means milk produced in Sydney on a Thursday can reach China by Sunday. Peloris now exports yoghurt, cheeses and seafood to China. The company has gone from being mostly retail to supplying food manufacturers in China - one of them being a frozen cake manufacturer. There are inquiries now from customers in China who are pulling all the US products off the shelf. A major food manufacturer is doing a product launch in August and needs to get everything done because they have ditched their American ingredients. Average US tariffs on Chinese goods are still above 50%. There is a big opportunity for Australian and New Zealand products whilst there’s this disruption to the US-China trade with the US tariffs. The opportunity is for Australia and New Zealand producers to actually get a foot in the door and build relationships with the Chinese buyers in retail and in wholesale food manufacturing. China still gets products from Europe, but Australia and New Zealand have inherent advantages in terms of the supply chain lead times. Peloris is talking to one New Zealand butter manufacturer (not Fonterra) and a cheese manufacturer about getting product into China by the end of the year. China was still a tough market regardless of the leg-up that local exporters might be getting from China’s issues with America.

title: Equity investors seeking clarity should be careful what they wish for
content: Financial markets famously hate uncertainty, but getting answers to many of the open questions currently hanging over markets may end up offering investors little comfort.
resumen:
Financial markets hate uncertainty, but getting answers to many of the open questions currently hanging over markets may end up offering investors little comfort.

Several recent global developments, including President Donald Trump’s April 2 tariff announcement and subsequent 90-day pause as well as the breakout of the Israel-Iran war, have sparked some of the highest levels of uncertainty in decades.

On July 9, the 90-day pause on Trump’s Liberation Day ‘reciprocal tariffs’ will end, and unless the delay is extended or multiple trade deals are struck, U.S. import tariffs will essentially double from the 10% level today.

So far, only the UK has managed to agree on a trade deal. Negotiations with the European Union and Japan have stalled, and the EU has prepared a range of potential retaliatory measures.

The U.S. Commerce Department is preparing to present its findings on investigations into semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, copper, aircraft, jet engines and a host of other goods. It is widely expected that once these findings are presented, the U.S. government will act quickly to impose additional tariffs or import restrictions.

The Senate is expected to vote on the Trump administration’s budget bill in July. The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that in its current form, this bill will add $3.3 trillion in extra debt over the coming decade.

Investor confidence in the dollar and the safety of U.S. Treasuries has been shaken recently, partly due to the country’s deteriorating fiscal outlook.

The war between Israel and Iran has been thrown into the mix, with the U.S. attacking Iranian nuclear sites on Sunday. Oil prices have increased by roughly 10% since the war broke out.

The tariffs currently in place could add 0.9 percentage points to U.S. inflation over the next 12 months. If there are no additional trade deals struck and tariffs revert to the higher levels announced on Liberation Day, another 0.7 percentage points could be added.

The inflation impact from the budget bill will likely be much smaller at roughly 0.1 percentage points over the next 12 months, and an oil price spike to $80 per barrel is apt to have roughly the same impact.

If oil prices spike to about $100 and remain in that region for the next six months, we would have to be seriously worried about an inflation shock from the war in the Middle East.

If all these developments, including a 20% oil price spike, come to pass, U.S. inflation could rise from current levels by up to two percentage points in the next twelve months.

U.S. stock markets have rallied 15% above the level justified by macroeconomic fundamentals, based on estimates.

Over the last 10 years, a deviation of this size was followed by an average decline of 7% in the S&P 500 in the subsequent three months.

The gap between performance and fundamentals is smaller in the euro zone and UK.

title: $92K dip vs ‘short-lived war’ — 5 things to know in Bitcoin this week
content: Bitcoin dipped to its lowest levels since early May before ultimately sealing a weekly close at around $101,000. Data from Cointelegraph Markets Pro and TradingView shows accelerating sell-side ...
resumen: Bitcoin (BTC) enters the last week of June with geopolitics at a key crossroads and macro volatility to match. Bitcoin traders are bracing for new lows as exchange order book liquidity shifts toward the $90,000 mark. Bitcoin dipped to its lowest levels since early May before ultimately sealing a weekly close at around $101,000. Data from Cointelegraph Markets Pro and TradingView shows accelerating sell-side pressure running out of steam near $98,000. Trader CrypNuevo warns that the next support retest may run deeper, with liquidity potentially at $95,000. Data from monitoring resource CoinGlass shows support staying in place higher up, in a range that coincides with the cost basis for investors holding BTC for six months or less. Onchain analytics firm Glassnode observed that since April, $BTC corrections have consistently found support at the Short-Term Holder Realized Price — the cost basis of investors holding <155 days. Glassnode flagged what it described as “rising pressure on newer investors,” with just 3% of the new investor cohort sitting on unrealized gains. Popular trader Roman forecasts a trip to $92,000 next for BTC/USD. The Federal Reserve’s “preferred” inflation gauge, the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index, is due for release on June 27. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is due to testify to the House Financial Services Committee on June 24-25. The Federal Reserve held rates at current levels on Wednesday, with the short-term fed funds rate unchanged at a range of 4.25% - 4.50%. The combined altcoin market cap, excluding the top ten cryptocurrencies, fell to $202.16 billion on Sunday — its lowest since April 18. Popular trader and analyst Rekt Capital said that historical patterns may repeat and support an altcoin rebound sooner rather than later. In previous cycles, Bitcoin dominance reached around 71% and then reversed. Bitcoin market participants broadly agree that the current bull market has room to run. Onchain analytics platform CryptoQuant leveraged the Bitcoin Yearly Percentage Trend (BYPT) tool to declare that 2025 is likely the last bullish year of the current cycle. Carmelo Aleman sees 120% gains in 2025 as a result of historical tendencies, giving BTC/USD a cycle top of over $200,000.

title: International Trade: Trump’s Chaos Will Reshape the System
content: The aggressive, unilateral tariff measures of the new US administration are set to usher in a more fragmented and unpredictable global order, increasingly shaped by geoeconomic confrontation.
resumen: The Trump administration is reshaping trade relations, agreements, and flows through the use of tariffs and threats. The US is now a rogue nation, and trade relations will be based on maximizing US advantage. Agreements with the US will be honored only as long as they benefit the US. The USMCA has been violated. Relief secured from tariffs could be temporary. The US will be a non-factor or an impediment in the WTO. The new trade system will be less cohesive and cooperative. New powers like China, India, and Brazil will play an assertive role. Flashpoints will arise over trade and values. Trump will intertwine trade and geopolitics more tightly. The US-UK trade deal provides an example of this. The US is withdrawing from the Paris Climate Accord. US emissions are likely headed up. China will be the global leader in green trade. The new world of trade that is emerging will be considerably more fractious and far less stable.

title: Planning around global tensions
content: The Iran-Israel conflict may drive up oil prices and shipping costs, factors that budget makers had assumed would remain ...
resumen:
For import-dependent Pakistan, another conflict in the neighbourhood is deeply alarming. Pakistan may be among the countries hardest hit by the ongoing Iran-Israel war, facing significant economic and social repercussions. Any widening of the conflict would multiply Pakistan’s economic and diplomatic challenges.

President Donald Trump promised not to directly target Iran for the next two weeks, sparking hopes for a ceasefire and a peace deal.

The timing of the war, breaking out as Pakistan was finalising its budget, has compounded challenges. It diverted focus from pressing domestic issues and disrupted key assumptions underlying the budget proposals.

Khurram Schehzad, a member of Prime Minister Shehbaz’s economic team, stated that budget planning is anchored in prudence, with built-in buffers to absorb external shocks, and there is no immediate need to revise projections unless global conditions deteriorate significantly.

The Iran-Israel conflict may drive up oil prices and shipping costs. Analysts agree that a prolonged conflict would almost certainly lead to significant increases. This would derail inflation targets, revive fiscal and current account pressures, strain foreign exchange reserves and weaken the rupee. It could also force the government to revisit or roll back revenue measures such as higher petroleum development levy and the proposed carbon tax.

Inflation, which has fallen from historic highs of 38 per cent in May 2023 to just 3.5pc by May 2025, is likely to surge again.

The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) opted to steady rates in its monetary policy announcement last Monday.

The investment rate is unlikely to pick up, further undermining GDP growth projections.

Dr Manzoor Ahmed, a trade expert and former Pakistan World Trade Organisation representative, said: “The immediate impact is a sharp rise in global oil prices, up nearly 7pc since hostilities began. For Pakistan, where imported energy accounts for 30pc of total imports, this is deeply concerning. Past crises, such as the 2008 Iraq war and 2022 Russia-Ukraine conflict, saw oil prices soar above $120 to $145 per barrel. If Iran closes the Strait of Hormuz, which handles a fifth of global oil trade, it would disrupt supply chains, spike freight and insurance costs, risk pushing major economies into recession. Such shocks would hit Pakistan’s exports and derail any fragile progress towards economic stability and growth.”

Mr Schehzad said: “While regional tensions warrant close monitoring, it’s important not to overstate their immediate economic impact on Pakistan.”

Younus Dagha, former federal secretary and Sindh minister and current Chairman of the Policy Research Advisory Council (PRAC), noted: “Wars and natural disasters can’t be fully accounted for during budget planning; provisions are made as events unfold. It’s impossible to predict whether the Iran-Israel conflict will end quickly or drag on for months. While PRAC has already questioned the growth and revenue targets in the 2025–26 budget, it remains too early to gauge how this crisis on our western border will affect the economy.”

Ehsan Malik, CEO of the Pakistan Business Council, said: “Middle East tensions are pushing up fuel costs and threatening supply through the Strait of Hormuz, which carries 15pc of global oil and 20pc of gas. The region supplies half the world’s energy. Brent crude has climbed to a five-month high at $77.2 per barrel. For Pakistan, which spends about $20 billion on oil and gas [a third of imports], a 7–10pc price hike could strain the external account by $1.5–2bn and weaken the rupee, especially against the euro. Higher fuel costs will fuel inflation, but fiscal space is too tight to lower the Petroleum Development Levy. There’s no need to delay the budget; any adjustments can be made through mini-budgets if needed.”

The ongoing conflict risks further destabilising Balochistan, which hosts some of the country’s largest China-Pakistan Economic Corridor infrastructure projects and rich mineral deposits. Pakistan has already tightened controls on the Afghanistan border and, following the Israel attack, sealed the key entry and exit points along its 560 miles border with Iran. Balochistan shares a 724-miles border with Afghanistan.

Majyd Aziz, former president of the Karachi Chamber of Commerce and Industry remarked, “Lessons must be learned from Yemen’s recent Suez Canal blockade — Pakistan typically holds only three weeks of oil reserves. Another risk is a potential influx of Iranian refugees into Balochistan. Furthermore, disruptions in sea routes could hamper exports, triggering factory closures if shipping lines reroute vessels.”

title: It isn't just the Strait of Hormuz. Oil traders and global investors await Iran's response to U.S. strike.
content: Stock-market investors were rattled, and oil futures jumped, after Israel began its assault on Iran on June 12. West Texas Intermediate crude (CL.1), the U.S. benchmark, ended Friday at $74.93, losing ...
resumen: Iran's ability to choke off the Strait of Hormuz is a key question for investors. The potential for Iran to shut down shipping routes, particularly the strait, through which ships carrying roughly 20 million barrels a day of oil and oil products and 20% of the world's liquefied-natural-gas supply, has long served as a boogeyman for investors, oil traders, shippers and world leaders. Following President Donald Trump's decision to involve the U.S. directly in the Israel-Iran war Saturday by bombing Iranian nuclear sites, the threat is front and center. Rebecca Babin, senior energy trader and managing director at CIBC Private Wealth in New York, said that while odds of a full closure of the Strait of Hormuz remain below 50%, they are clearly higher than they were on Friday. The more immediate and likely scenario, she said, is increased harassment of vessels, through tactics like mining and boarding, that would raise transit times and shipping costs without a formal closure. The uncertainty is almost certain to spark a rally in crude when the market opens Sunday night. The market will be watching two key things: first, whether Iran's response includes energy infrastructure; and second, it if does, how long any disruptions could realistically persist, Babin said. News reports said Iran's parliament had endorsed closing the strait, though the body doesn't have the authority to implement, as such action would require approval from the Supreme Leader's council, Babin noted. If the Strait of Hormuz became non-navigable, it would constitute pretty much an unprecedented negative supply shock for the energy markets, at least in recent history, said Minna Kuusisto, chief analyst at Danske Bank in Copenhagen. Economists at Oxford Economics, in a June 20 report, warned that a "worst-case scenario" could see oil prices spike to $130 a barrel and shave 0.8 percentage points off of global gross domestic product. Flows through the Strait of Hormuz in 2024 and the first quarter of 2025 made up more than a quarter of total global seaborne oil trade and about a fifth of global oil and petroleum-product consumption, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said in a June 16 report. In addition, around 20% of global liquefied natural gas trade also moved through the strait in 2024. West Texas Intermediate crude (CL.1), the U.S. benchmark, ended Friday at $74.93, losing 22 cents. The S&P 500 SPX fell 0.2% on the week, ending Friday at 5,967.84, still just 2.9% below its record finish of Feb. 19. The U.S. has amassed a massive military presence in the Gulf and surrounding region, and a move by Iran against the strait would almost certainly trigger a significant military response, said Gregory Brew, senior analyst for Iran and energy at Eurasia Group. Increased Iranian harassment of tanker traffic is likely in coming days. Vice President J.D. Vance said any effort to disrupt shipping in the Strait of Hormuz would be "suicidal" for Iran. Danske Bank's Kuusisto said an attempt to close the strait would likely be viewed by Iran as its last option, noting that the strait is vital to the nation's ailing economy. Almost all of Iran's oil exports go to China.

title: Tariffs: Risks and opportunities for small-caps
content: News archive including articles on Fund Managers, Fund Selection, Asset Allocation, Absolute Return, Offshore Investments, Tax Shelters, Insurance bonds. Tariffs: Risks and opportunities for small-cap ...
resumen:
On 2 April 2025, US president Donald Trump announced extensive tariffs on almost every country worldwide. These tariffs have significantly impacted countries and regions including Europe, China and south-east Asia. Higher tariffs tend to slow economic activity, which can disproportionately impact small-cap stocks. Small-cap stocks have experienced a notable sell-off since last November.

Industrials: Money transfer companies like Brinks or Loomis are unlikely to face any negative impacts. School bus manufacturer Bluebird sources components from Canada and Mexico and buys most of its steel from the US, but tariffs on imports will increase domestic prices.

Automobiles: The Trump administration opted out imposing reciprocal tariffs on imported vehicles, with Canada and Mexico exempt from reciprocal tariffs. Thanks to the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), auto suppliers remain exempt from tariffs. US-made cars will get a reimbursement of 3.75% of the manufacturer’s suggested retail price (MSRP) for tariffs paid on non-US content.

Residential real estate: Tariffs may lead to cost increases for homebuilders. The Federal Reserve is cautious about lowering interest rates due to inflation concerns.

Consumer staples: Tariffs can still have unique effects on these companies. Spectrum Brands wants to sell its home appliances business, with tariffs on the imported parts and materials complicating valuations.

Specialty retail: Many clothing brands have moved production to south-east Asia, shifting from China to countries like India, Vietnam and Cambodia, which are experiencing higher tariffs. Luxury fashion company Capri Holdings is facing challenges from tariffs because of its manufacturing presence in south-east Asia.

Energy: Tariffs won’t directly impact energy, but energy demand may decline if trade barriers impede the US economy. Crude oil prices fell following the tariff announcements.

Healthcare: Enovis, orthopaedic components producer, imports materials from a textile factory in Mexico - 90% of which are exempt from tariffs under the USMCA. Tariffs on steel and aluminium will affect the company’s implants business. The company expects the net cost of tariffs to be slightly less than its previous estimate of $3m to $4m monthly. Embecta, a manufacturer of insulin delivery devices, produces a pen needle in Europe that’s sold in the US The company’s products qualify for tariff exemptions under the Nairobi Protocol.

Real estate investment trusts: Lodging and retail REITs may face headwinds if higher prices reduce consumer spending on travel. Industrial REITs could experience lower demand at ports but also benefit from reshoring. Health care and other triple-net REITs are likely the most insulated from tariffs.

Jeff John, Ryan Cope, Tyler Dunaway and George Clark run the American Century Small Cap Value fund.

title: Week Ahead: Markets Brace for Tariff Deadlines as Israel-Iran War Enters New Phase
content: Euro US Dollar, British Pound US Dollar, US Dollar Japanese Yen, US Dollar Swiss Franc. Read 's Market Analysis on Investing.com ...
resumen: The Israel-Iran war continues, but capital markets have barely reacted outside of oil. WTI rose by about 2.7% last week after a 13% rally the previous week, reaching levels not seen since early January. The average retail price of unleaded gasoline has risen by almost 2.5% this month. The price of gold fell by nearly 2% last week, its first weekly decline in three. The dollar rose against all of the G10 currencies. US tariff threats, with postponement of the so-called reciprocal tariffs coming to an end on July 9, continue to cast a long shadow. The recent doubling of the US steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% seems to make things more complicated. US real sector data continues to surprise on the downside, including May retail sales, industrial production, and housing starts. The FOMC indicated it is in no hurry to change policy, and despite Governor Waller suggesting a July cut is possible, the market does not believe it. September is a different story, and Fed funds futures are discounting around an 80% chance of a cut then. NATO has much to consider when it meets at the start of the new week. President Trump has said he will decide about increasing the US role against Iran in the next two weeks, by which time, Israel’s operation will be over or nearly so. The penetration depth of the "bunker buster" bomb is estimated to be about 200 feet (61 meters), and the Israeli intelligence estimates the facility may be as much as 300 feet below the surface. The economic diaries are fairly light in the week ahead. The flash PMI starts the new week. US CPI and PPI have stolen the thunder from the PCE deflators. Tokyo’s June CPI is expected to moderate slightly. Mexico’s central bank is expected to deliver another 50 bp cut. The end of the postponement of the so-called reciprocal tariffs is early July, and ahead of it, Trump has said he would send letters to countries, announcing the new bilateral tariffs. The new phase in the Israel-Iran war can become more impact for the dollar if the US takes a more direct role or if the war widens. The cost of insurance may be slowing activity in the Gulf of Hormuz more than Iranian forces. The market has little reason to react much to the survey data in the coming days, which include the preliminary PMI, several regional Fed surveys, and the Conference Board’s measure of consumer confidence. Given the tariffs, the May goods trade balance will be of interest. Weekly jobless claims will also draw attention given the recent rise in the four-week moving average to the highest since August 2023 and the elevated continuing claims. A surge of orders for Boeing (NYSE:BA) (303) in May will lift durable goods orders after a sharp 6.3% decline in April. The 1.5% decline in April orders excluding aircraft and defense was the largest drop since February 2023. Personal income and consumption data will help fine-tune Q2 GDP forecasts, which the Atlanta Fed says is tracking 3.4% and the median projection by economists in Bloomberg’s survey is 1.4%. Details for the CPI and PPI suggest the PCE deflator will tick up to 2.3% from 2.1% at the headline level and 2.6% from 2.5% at the core level. The Dollar Index consolidated last week at somewhat firmer levels. The trendline begins the new week near 98.65. The momentum indicators suggest a consolidative/corrective phase may be at hand. The five-day moving average looks poised to cross above the 20-day moving average in the coming days. The initial target may be in the 100.00-50 area. The euro benefits from being the un-cola to the dollar’s Coca-Cola (NYSE:KO). After a pause in the coming months, the swaps market is pricing in one more cut before the end of the year, which would bring the deposit rate to 1.75%. The markets may be more sensitive to the eurozone’s PMI than the US. The composite PMI slipped in April and May. May auto registrations, a proxy for sales are due. April showed the first increase year-over-year here in 2025. They rose 1.3%. Germany’s June IFO is due. The euro pulled back from $1.1630 reached on June 12, the highest level since October 2021. It recorded a low, a week later, near $1.1445, and found support slightly ahead of the 20-day moving average, which it has not traded below since the end of May. Nearby resistance is seen in the $1.1550-60 area. A consolidative/corrective phase can continue if the resistance holds. On the downside, a break of $1.1440 could see $1.1380 initially. China maintains a firm hand managing the yuan. Beijing is committed to maintaining the broad stability of the yuan against the dollar. China’s economy is struggling to sustain the momentum necessary to achieve its growth target and deflation continues to grip. The PBOC has been steadily lowering the dollar’s fix in recent weeks. Before the weekend, the fix was set at its lowest level in three months (CNY7.1695). The setting of the daily reference rate is among the most powerful tools at Chinese official disposal to manage the exchange rate. Since earlier this month, the greenback has been consolidating between roughly CNH7.1650 and CNH7.2000. The yen’s sensitivity to US interest rates has increased over the last few weeks. The rolling 30-day correlation of changes in the exchange rate and the US 10-year yield has risen to 0.48 from slightly below 0.10 a month ago. The Israel-Iran conflict did not spur a safe haven rally in the yen. Japan has the highest inflation in the G10, but the central bank is clearly reluctant to hike rates. Its bond and equity markets are the worst-performing in the G7 so far this year. Japan sees the latest employment figures and retail sales, but arguably the most important report is the Tokyo’s June CPI. Bank of Japan Governor Ueda rhetoric has been toned down. The swaps market sees the year-end target rate at almost 0.60%, down about 25 bp since late March. The dollar posted its biggest weekly advance of the year against the yen, almost 1.40%. It set the high for the month before the weekend, slightly above of JPY146.20. A move above the JPY146.30 area could spur a move toward JPY147.00-15 next. The momentum indicators are constructive. Initial support may be around JPY144.35. Sterling’s 7.6% gain this year against the dollar largely reflects the greenback’s weakness

title: 15 Irish citizens evacuated from Israel, says Tánaiste
content: Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Harris has said that 15 Irish citizens who were seeking to leave Israel have been evacuated.
resumen: Tánaiste Simon Harris said that 15 Irish citizens who were seeking to leave Israel have been evacuated. They left Israel in operations organised by Austria, and they are expected to arrive in Ireland in the coming days. A "small number" of citizens also want to leave Iran and work is under way to get them out too. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Embassy in Tel Aviv have remained in regular contact with Irish citizens in the region. Irish citizens who choose to stay in Iran and Israel should monitor developments and register with the nearest Irish embassy, if they have not already done so. Embassies will remain in close contact with all citizens in Israel and Iran over the days and weeks ahead. The Tánaiste spoke with the Iranian deputy foreign minister. Taoiseach Micheál Martin called for an urgent need for de-escalation, dialogue and diplomacy.

title: “Too late” Powell gets it wrong again
content: Op-ed views and opinions expressed are solely those of the author. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has made yet another serious mistake—one in a long series of […] ...
resumen: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has made another serious mistake in a series of policy missteps. Powell continues to deliver vague commentary about “future inflation risks” while keeping rates at unnecessarily restrictive levels. The Federal Funds Rate should not be this high. Most economists agree that a Fed Funds Rate in the range of 3.25% to 3.5% is considered “neutral.” The current rate stands at 5.3%. The Fed is actively working to restrain an economy that is already slowing down. Inflation surged to over 9% in mid-2022. From January 2021 to June 2022, Powell held rates too low while prices skyrocketed. The Fed aggressively raised interest rates in June 2022. Growth is weakening. GDP growth dropped from 3% in the summer of last year to 2.3% by fall. Growth turned negative in the first quarter. The soft labor market has the unemployment rate ready to creep higher. Interest rate cuts are not only justified—they are overdue. Powell refuses to act. His latest reasoning centers on concerns that the Trump administration’s tariff policy could reignite inflation. Except for trade with China, the tariffs will be moderate. Most countries and most imports would face a 10% rate. Higher tariffs would apply to a narrow range of products tied to national security. Those modest tariff-related price pressures would be offset by falling energy prices. Energy costs—including gasoline—are expected to drop sharply. In 2018, Powell raised interest rates four times without a clear economic justification. He had to walk those increases back in 2019. President Trump has called on the Fed to cut rates by 100 basis points—a full percentage point. That would bring the Fed Funds Rate down to approximately 3.3%. The Fed’s current stance is suffocating the housing market. Mortgage rates are hovering near 7%. Federal Housing Finance Agency Director William Pulte has called for Powell’s immediate resignation if rates aren’t lowered soon. “Because President Trump has crushed inflation, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell needs to lower interest rates today,” Pulte wrote. “And if not, Chairman Powell needs to resign immediately. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac can help so many more Americans if Chair Powell would just do his job and lower rates.” Powell’s tenure as Fed Chair has been defined by poor timing, reactive decision-making, and a failure to read economic signals in real time. He was too slow to raise rates when inflation took off. Now, he’s too slow to cut them as growth stalls. President Trump, Director Pulte, and a growing chorus of economic observers are right— “too late” Powell needs to cut interest rates now or resign. If he doesn’t step down, Trump won’t be able to replace him until May 2026. The Fed must cut interest rates now.
