title: Trump and the Middle East Weigh on the Fed
content: Investors are anxious about whether the central bank will change course on rate cuts as geopolitical turmoil and tariffs pose inflation risks.
resumen:
On Wednesday, Jay Powell, the Fed chair, will likely face questions about the economic impact of conflict in the Middle East and how it might change the central bank’s forecasts about interest rates in the coming months.

The central bank is widely expected to hold interest rates steady on Wednesday. Markets will be watching closely the Fed’s rates forecast and Jay Powell’s news conference. High on the agenda will be questions about whether the Fed chair sees conflict in the Middle East and higher oil prices creating a new inflation risk that forces the central bank to keep rates higher for longer.

In March, the Fed signaled that it would lower its benchmark lending rate by half a percentage point this year.

Trump has repeatedly chided Powell for not cutting rates sooner, arguing that two full percentage points of cuts are warranted.

Moody’s cut America’s triple-A credit rating.

Nonpartisan congressional analysts estimate that the House version of Republicans’ huge policy bill would grow the national debt by $3.4 trillion.

The Israel-Iran conflict and Trump’s on-again-off-again tariff approach threaten to reignite inflation.

Bank of America forecasts that the Fed will make just one quarter-point cut this year.

Economists at Goldman Sachs see the Fed going with two cuts this year.

The futures market is pricing in two cuts on Wednesday.

Trump has said he plans to name a successor soon, even though Powell’s term as Fed chair doesn’t end until May.

Trump and Powell do not see eye to eye on the economy or on rates policy.

The Trump administration sends conflicting messages on immigration raids.

The Department of Homeland Security has reversed guidance exempting farms and hotels from raids.

A new poll showed that 42 percent of Americans oppose the legislation, while 23 percent support it.

The Senate passes a landmark crypto bill.

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick talks up the “Trump Card.” A website promoting the proposed visa, which would cost $5 million and give foreigners a pathway to legal residency in the U.S., has racked up more than 68,000 registrations of interest.

With Elon Musk seemingly well and truly on the outs with President Trump, the fallout may be felt as far as Beijing.

Musk’s ties to China — where Tesla produces half its cars — were among the most glaring.

Musk’s efforts to spearhead cost cuts at the so-called Department of Government Efficiency were also troublesome.

DOGE cuts to agencies like the Labor Department and the Department of Homeland Security have hamstrung those agencies’ ability to monitor China’s business and trade dealings with Washington.

Beijing has a trump card with its lock on rare earth supplies, which are vital to Tesla and other American carmakers.

Sam Altman, OpenAI’s C.E.O., threw a jab at his company’s rival Meta.

Andy Jassy, Amazon’s C.E.O., told the tech and retail giant’s 1.5 million workers that he believes the “once-in-a-lifetime” technology will eventually lead to fewer of them working at the company.

Allison Kirkby, the C.E.O. of the British telecom BT, said that the technology could help her trim even more jobs and costs at the business. She has already announced plans to cut more than 40,000 positions and 3 billion pounds ($4 billion) in costs by the end of the decade.

Sebastian Siemiatkowski, the C.E.O. of the payments company Klarna, has long spoken about how A.I. is helping his business shed jobs.

Jensen Huang, the C.E.O. of Nvidia, said “some jobs will be obsolete” because of A.I.

Pope Leo XIV is making the technology and its potential threat to humanity a key focus of his papacy.

AXA is the top user of A.I. in the insurance industry, according to a new ranking by Evident.

Elon Musk’s xAI is said to be close to raising $9.3 billion in equity and debt from investors.

Democratic lawmakers are demanding information on the consulting firm Palantir’s more than $100 million worth of government contracts since Inauguration Day.

Chase is raising the annual fee for its Chase Sapphire Reserve card to $795.

title: Short deadline for Canada-U.S. talks helps to ‘concentrate the mind,’ Carney says
content: Mr. Carney’s comments capped a two-day summit that managed to avoid the kind of blow-up that marred the G7 meeting in Charlevoix, Que., in 2018, where Mr. Trump called then-prime-minister Justin ...
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney, a day after setting a 30-day target for a landmark economic and security deal with Donald Trump, declined to explain why he selected the time frame, what kind of agreement could be achieved in that period or what would happen if the talks failed.

Mr. Carney told reporters at the conclusion of the Group of Seven leaders summit in Canada’s Rocky Mountains that a fixed date helps people focus.

Mr. Carney’s comments capped a two-day summit that managed to avoid the kind of blow-up that marred the G7 meeting in Charlevoix, Que., in 2018, where Mr. Trump called then-prime-minister Justin Trudeau “dishonest and weak.”

Several joint statements issued by the G7 leaders generated little in the way of new collaborative action on big issues, aside from closer co-operation on critical minerals and transnational repression.

And Canada’s efforts to demonstrate collective action on Russia’s war on Ukraine fell through.

As in 2018, Mr. Trump quit the 2025 summit early, disrupting plans by multiple world leaders to meet with him in Canada – and before the group could gather jointly with Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelensky.

The U.S. President used his brief time at the summit to lament Russia’s expulsion from the diplomatic forum.

Mr. Carney signalled Canada is looking closely at steel dumping as it negotiates a trade deal with the United States, an indication that Ottawa is prepared to respond to American concerns over the dumping of Chinese commodities on North American markets.

Mr. Carney did not mention China by name.

He described a “need to provide protections” against “third-country flows of steel – and mainly steel, but possibly aluminum – into Canada.”

Canadian negotiators have sought to allay Mr. Trump’s concerns as they push for the cancellation of all import taxes on Canadian goods, a stand in direct opposition to the U.S. President’s deep fondness for tariffs as a tool for raising revenue and boosting the prospects of domestic industry.

Mr. Carney acknowledged Tuesday, speaking at the close of the G7 summit, “That’s our position. And at present, the United States may have a slightly different position.”

An estimated 10 per cent of exported Chinese steel is transshipped through third countries, a trade worth roughly US$7-billion.

Canada has already placed a 25-per-cent tariff on Chinese steel.

Mr. Carney and the U.S. President on Monday agreed to accelerated negotiations with the aim of striking “within the coming 30 days” an economic and security deal that would end the Canada-U.S. trade war.

The commitment followed a 70-minute meeting between Mr. Carney and Mr. Trump at the start of the G7 summit.

Further Canada-U.S. talks are scheduled for later this week.

Mr. Trump, who told reporters this week he thought a deal with Canada was achievable, suggested that Canadians will end up paying tariffs even if the trade war is resolved.

Speaking to reporters on Air Force One as he headed home Monday, he again pitched the idea of Canada becoming the 51st state, saying if this country forgoes annexation, “they’re going to have to pay a lot of tariffs and things.”

Brian Clow, who served as deputy chief of staff to Mr. Trudeau, said he thinks the 30-day deal deadline is “aspirational” rather than a hard target.

Mr. Clow said the commitment to reach a deal within 30 days is a useful tactic to keep the United States engaged as Washington is busy negotiating with more than 15 other countries on their own deals.

The Wall Street Journal, citing an unidentified U.S. official, reported that Mr. Trump complained about Canada’s protectionism on dairy products during his talk with Mr. Carney in Kananaskis, Alta., saying its dairy industry was rigged against the U.S. because of high tariffs.

David Paterson, Ontario’s trade representative in Washington, said, “Officially everybody wants to get to zero tariffs, but we also have heard consistently from the U.S. administration that they’re wanting to maintain a degree of tariff on everybody. And that’s why we don’t have a deal yet.”

Scrapping Canada’s digital services tax is among U.S. demands in trade talks with Canada.

The 30-day negotiating window encompasses one important date: June 30, the deadline for companies to pay amounts owed under Canada’s digital services tax, a 3-per-cent charge on revenues collected by large multinational companies that is retroactive to Jan. 1, 2022.

The U.S. has fought the tax, saying it places an unfair burden on American companies and is filing a dispute under the U.S.-Mexico-Canada agreement.

In his conversation with reporters on Air Force One on Monday, Mr. Trump also said Canada will have to pay dearly to become part of the American ”Golden Dome” missile defence system.

He had earlier said the price of admission for Ottawa would be US$61-billion.

On Monday night, he said it would be US$71-billion.

On Monday, Canada’s ambassador to the U.S., Kirsten Hillman, said that Ottawa continues to argue that Mr. Trump should cut his import taxes to zero.

Canada has pursued a two-phase approach to trade talks with the U.S., hoping for an interim deal that can be followed by a broader discussion about new terms under the USMCA.

title: Trump's trade wars threaten the WTO, and may mean the end of globalization as we know it
content: The World Trade Organization promised a future of unlimited growth, but became a bogeyman for the left. Now its future is increasingly clouded thanks to Donald Trump. A look at globalization's ...
resumen:
The World Trade Organization (WTO) promised unlimited growth but faced criticism, particularly from the left. Its future is threatened by U.S. President Donald Trump, who wants a geoeconomic world order based on his rules. Trump criticized the 1994 WTO agreement, calling it a "disaster for America" and has a strong belief in tariffs. April 2, 2025, when Trump announced "reciprocal tariffs," is seen as a turning point. The U.S., once a champion of open markets, is now undermining the system it created. The WTO has been demonized by the left since its inception 30 years ago.

The liberalization of global trade boosts prosperity, as described by David Ricardo's theory of comparative advantage. In 1947, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) entered into force. The WTO replaced GATT in 1995, aiming for broader liberalization. The WTO, based in Geneva, was intended to resolve disputes. Renato Ruggiero, the first director-general of the WTO, said that the world would be a better place if no country is allowed to discriminate against another.

Critics of globalization warned of "colonialism" and cultural homogenization. The WTO is a secretariat that moderates and coordinates global trade. At the 1999 WTO summit in Seattle, protests escalated. Pat Buchanan, a conservative, opposed "globalists" and predicted factory closures and loss of sovereignty due to the WTO agreement.

Global trade volume increased by 125% by 2008, but major liberalization steps stalled. The unanimity principle has blocked progress. There has been increasing competition for bilateral and regional free trade agreements. China joined the WTO in 2001, and has benefited from it. Trump imposed new tariffs during his first term. The U.S. has crippled the dispute-resolution system by blocking appointments to the Appellate Body since 2019. More than 50 countries have agreed to an alternative dispute-settlement mechanism.

Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala argues that the WTO is not finished. Roberto Azevêdo, Okonjo-Iweala's predecessor, said that the system is dead as it was known.

title: WTO director defends organisation amid concerns being raised by OECS countries
content: The Director General of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, said on Tuesday that the global community is facing very challenging times with respect to trade and that this is ...
resumen: The Director General of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, addressed the seventh meeting of the OECS Assembly. She stated that the global community is facing challenging times with respect to trade, possibly the most disruptive period since the 1930s. Dominica and Antigua and Barbuda have warned that unless the rules of engagement are observed, “these institutions will not work for us.” Antigua and Barbuda’s Foreign Affairs, Immigration and Trade Minister, E P Chet Greene, said that the Caribbean's danger is the slow suffocation of economies and the stagnation of societies. Okonjo-Iweala said the decision by the United States to impose a tariff on countries, including those in the Caribbean, could result in a contraction of global trade by about 0.2 per cent. United States President Donald Trump has implemented the trade tariffs. Okonjo-Iweala said that the WTO has been modelling every single change. She said that for the OECS countries, their economies are service economies, “and therefore, mainly, are not as impacted by these tariffs as they could have been. Okonjo-Iweala said in her discussions with the United States representatives, the approach of unilateralism to solve the problem was probably not the best one to take. She said article 28 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) enables a member who is no longer pleased with the situation of the tariffs to come back and say to other members, “we want to relook at this.”. She said that the OECS countries will have an occasion to do that at the 14th ministerial meeting of the WTO in March next year. She said developing countries such as the OECS have also been critical of the system, on the grounds that it hasn’t delivered as much for them. Skerrit said that the new world order is moving towards a unilateral system. Antigua and Barbuda’s Foreign Affairs, Immigration and Trade Minister, E P Chet Greene, told the OECS Assembly that many of the major international institutions are in a state of decline.

title: Trump’s Counterproductive Global South Policy
content: Imperialist, exploitative and egocentric — these words describe U.S. policy on the Global South. The policy is deeply ingrained in Trump MAGA agenda, but it’s a loser in the long run.
resumen:
The article, "Trump’s Counterproductive Global South Policy" by Zhou Xiaoming, discusses U.S. policy towards the Global South, characterizing it as imperialist, exploitative, and egocentric, deeply rooted in the Trump MAGA agenda.

In early May, the U.S. renounced the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), specifically the 17 goals adopted by all 193 UN members in 2015, including providing clean water, sanitation, and quality education, and tackling climate change. Edward Heartney, the U.S. counselor for economic and social affairs at the U.S. mission to the UN, stated that the U.S. rejects the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the SDGs because they are inconsistent with U.S. sovereignty and adverse to the rights and interests of Americans.

The author argues that Washington has never been genuinely interested in the development of poor nations, with official development assistance largely serving self-serving purposes, such as gaining market access, promoting values, and engineering regime change, as well as being geopolitically driven.

Donald Trump's renunciation of the SDGs aligns with his general approach to the Global South. The day after he returned to the White House, Trump initiated the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. In May, his administration announced its pullout from the UN-backed Loss and Damage Fund. The Trump administration is attempting to shift U.S. responsibility for climate change cleanup to its own victims.

Trump also pulled the U.S. out of the World Health Organization (WHO). The Trump administration pushes for U.S. defense spending to be increased to $1.01 trillion for fiscal year 2026, a jump of 13 percent year-on-year.

Trump is expected to dramatically slash international development assistance. Secretary of State Marco Rubio stated that aid is designed to further the national interests of the United States.

Trump has tried to extort wealth from the Global South through reciprocal tariffs, which hit developing countries particularly hard. Among 27 countries subject to tariff rates exceeding 30 percent, all but one are from the Global South. Trump’s 37 percent tariff on Bangladesh threatens to decimate the country’s garment industry, which accounts for nearly 85 percent of its exports and employs more 4 million workers. For around 30 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, Trump’s reciprocal tariffs nullify the preferential treatment under the African Growth and Opportunity Act. Lesotho faces the top rate of 50 percent. In contrast, China offers tariff-free access for all imports from all 53 African countries with which it has diplomatic ties.

Trump treats developing countries as inferiors and is obsessed with power politics. He is always ready to wield U.S. power to have his way with poor countries. He loves to set rules for the Global South as he pleases.

In 2018, Trump referred to Haiti and African nations as “shit-hole” countries.

The Trump administration's engagement with the Global South is largely driven by securing access to critical minerals and keeping China down. Trump said he would buy Greenland and threatened to use force to acquire the territory if necessary. In Asia, the Trump administration is actively pursuing a strategic partnership with Indonesia and Uzbekistan. In Africa, it is negotiating with the Democratic Republic of the Congo for cobalt and other strategic minerals. Trump is cultivating personal ties with Argentina’s President Javier Milei, largely aiming at the country’s lithium deposits.

The Trump administration uses interactions to undermine China’s ties with other developing countries. U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent smeared China’s economic and commercial activities in Latin America. The administration coerces countries to sever ties with China. It forced the Panamanian government to quit China’s Belt and Road Initiative and threatened Argentina with withdrawal of U.S. support for loans from the International Monetary Fund.

Trump demands that trading partners scale back Chinese imports and restrict Chinese investment.

Warren Buffet stated that Trump’s Global South policy was a “big mistake.”

title: Austria pushes EU to keep door open for Russian gas after war in Ukraine
content: Austria called on the European Union to leave the door open for the return of Russian gas imports after the conflict in Ukraine is over, while Brussels suggested imposing a complete ban on all Russian ...
resumen: Austria is pushing the EU to keep the door open for Russian gas imports after the war in Ukraine. The European Commission proposed cutting Russian gas imports completely by 2028. Austria called on the EU to leave the option open for the return of Russian gas imports after the conflict. The Austrian energy ministry stated that the bloc "must maintain the option to reassess the situation once the war has ended." Elisabeth Zehetner, Austrian state secretary for energy, made the remarks at an EU energy ministers' meeting in Luxembourg. The European Commission proposed cutting Russian gas imports completely by 2028. The proposed bill aims to create a legally binding ban. EU energy commissioner Dan Jørgensen dismissed Austria's argument. The Commission plan involves invoking a World Trade Organization "security exemption" provision. Austria has long relied on Russian gas, with imports before the war accounting for about 80% of its intake. OMV, Austria's state-owned energy firm, cut ties with Russian gas monopoly Gazprom last December. Leonore Gewessler, Austria's former energy minister, said the new Austrian position was "a totally wrong path." Austria has been importing more gas through Germany. EU imports of Russian liquefied natural gas (LNG) have risen, reaching a record 16.5 million tonnes in 2023. The Commission proposal would also prevent infrastructure projects like the Nord Stream pipelines.

title: Anthony Scaramucci on how to handle Trump: «Treat him like he’s a reality TV producer»
content: Anthony Scaramucci, the Wall Street financier who briefly worked as Donald Trump's White House communications director, once believed the president would help heal a divided nation. Now, he says, he ...
resumen: Anthony Scaramucci, the former White House communications director, supported Donald Trump's 2016 campaign and served on the transition team. He now considers Trump a danger to the country. Scaramucci believes he made a mistake supporting Trump. He says he was fired because he pointed out to Trump that he didn't think it was a good idea to veto sanctions against Russia. Scaramucci says Trump is offended by advice. He broke with Trump by August 2019. Scaramucci says the way to handle Trump is to treat him like he's a reality television producer.

title: project44 rolls out AI tool focused on helping companies Improve supply chain decisions
content: The tool helps companies spot delays and take quick action—automatically rescheduling, rerouting, or notifying teams in real time.
resumen: Chicago-based supply chain visibility services provider project44 has launched a new tool called Decision Intelligence, a major update to its Movement platform that goes beyond tracking shipments. The idea is to help businesses not just see where things are, but actually decide what to do when something goes wrong—or better yet, before it does. The company says the tool can connect to systems like SAP and Oracle, then use artificial intelligence to spot delays, suggest fixes, and even carry them out automatically. “AI that doesn’t lead to action is just another dashboard,” said Jett McCandless, Founder and CEO of project44. “With Decision Intelligence, we’re giving companies the power to make smart decisions automatically—based on real-time data, not guesswork.”

title: China Is Unleashing a New Export Shock on the World
content: As President Trump’s tariffs close off the U.S. market, Chinese goods are flooding countries from Southeast Asia to Europe to Latin America.
resumen: Two decades ago, China shocked the United States with its ability to make and ship things fast and inexpensively. Today, a new China shock is cascading across the globe from Indonesia to Germany to Brazil. As President Trump’s tariffs start to shut China out of the United States, its biggest market, Chinese factories are sending their toys, cars and shoes to other countries at a pace that is reshaping economies and geopolitics. This year so far, China’s trade surplus with the world is nearly $500 billion — a more than 40 percent increase from the same period last year. China has loads of things that it needs to export. The flood of exports from China is the consequence of government policy and a slowing domestic economy. Beijing has for several years been shoveling money into its manufacturing sectors, which are making far more things than there is demand for at home. China’s global market share for all categories of goods has risen sharply. By diverting the flow of its stuff to Southeast Asia, Latin America and Europe, China has already eased the economic effect of a plunge in demand from the United States. Mr. Trump is threatening steep tariffs for the same countries that are being inundated with more Chinese goods, like Vietnam, Cambodia and Indonesia. Some countries have benefited from an increase in investment by foreign companies that are trying to shift production from China as quickly as possible. If they cannot negotiate the tariffs much lower, homegrown companies in countries facing severe U.S. tariffs in Southeast Asia and elsewhere could be crushed by competition from Chinese companies. China’s property crisis — a glut of housing, plunging prices and widespread bankruptcies — began to reverberate through the economy in 2021. China’s policymakers wasted no time diverting cheap loans away from developers to exporters and manufacturers. China had already embarked on a domestic industrial policy in 2015, known as Made in China 2025, to make higher-skilled, more valuable goods like sophisticated computer chips and electric vehicles. China’s drive to boost manufacturing since the property market collapse has gone much further. Even while making more advanced products, Chinese manufacturers doubled down on making tchotchkes, the kinds of cheaper things that China excelled at making two decades ago. China is not developing the way economic theory suggests. In Germany, where shipments of Chinese goods last month rose 20 percent from a year earlier, companies have expressed concerns. China has made 45 percent more electric vehicles this year. Exports of electric vehicles have soared 64.6 percent this year, according to the Chinese Association of Automobile Manufacturers. In Indonesia, garment factories are closing. Some 250,000 people lost their jobs in the garment industry in 2023 and 2024. Thai auto parts manufacturers have shut down because of Chinese electric vehicles. Brazilian carmakers have called on the government to initiate an antidumping probe into Chinese cars sold in the country. The first option is to do nothing and watch manufacturing get hollowed out. The other option is to raise tariffs and use other protectionist measures in specific sectors, just as the United States has done with China.

title: EU chief agrees with Trump on China trade issues, declares ‘Donald is right’
content: EU President Ursula von der Leyen agrees with President Donald Trump on China trade policies at G7, stating "Donald is right" about China's export restrictions.

title: Experts examine Michigan and Canada’s economic ties amid uncertainty from tariffs
content: Though proponents of Trump’s tariffs on Canada frequently ... also known as the USMCA. Windsor Mayor Drew Dilkens discusses the history of U.S.-Canadian trade during a June 17, 2025 policy forum. | ...
resumen:
A group of panelists from the U.S. and Canada discussed the economic ties between the nations and approaches to a new trade deal. The forum was hosted by Michigan State University’s Institute for Public Policy and Social Research, alongside the college’s Canadian Studies Center. Panelists included Jason Miller, interim chair of Michigan State University’s Department of Supply Chain Management; Windsor Mayor Drew Dilkens; and the Consul General of Canada in Detroit Colin Bird.

2025 has marked the largest tariff shock, with tariffs on Canada increasing by 19 times in April and March from January. U.S. importers are paying 3.5 times more in tariffs than in 2018 and 2019. Tariffs on steel and aluminum increased to 50% earlier this month. Over 60% of goods brought into Michigan from Canada are finished vehicles or auto parts. Roughly 53% of Michigan’s exports to Canada are finished vehicles and parts, totaling nearly $13 billion. Half of an auto plant's output from Michigan goes to Canada each year. Companies frontloaded exports in March, leading to a sharp decline in April. Vehicle imports also showed frontloading, but the drop was less pronounced in April when Trump levied a 25% tariff on vehicles from nations including Canada and Mexico. If the import of crude oil is excluded, the U.S. holds a trade surplus over Canada.

Dilkens discussed the history of trade agreements, starting with the Canada-U.S. Auto Pact of 1965. The auto pact later spawned the U.S.’s free trade agreement with Canada, which evolved into the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico in the 1990s, and then the U.S. Mexico Canada Trade Agreement (USMCA). Dilkens expressed hope that the nations could return to that agreement.

Bird emphasized the interconnection, noting that both nations built a support infrastructure of aluminum and steel during World War II. The U.S. imports 60% of its aluminum from Canada. Levies on aluminum imports are set to hit manufacturers hard. Bird warned about the impact this policy will have on Michigan.

Miller emphasized that it takes months for companies to begin shifting production, pointing to plans from General Motors to shift production away from Mexico back to the U.S. beginning in 2027. Automakers will take 12 to 18 months to shift production back to existing plants in the U.S., and getting new ones up and running will take at least four years.

The uncertainty sparked by Trump’s tariffs has caused companies to freeze. Miller predicted a decrease in the variety of goods available as companies focus more on producing their best sellers. A recent survey from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta found 45% of executives polled planned to scale back their investments, while 4% planned to expand. The U.S. economy is not in a recession.

Bird said he was hearing the same thing from companies in Canada and Michigan: “We’re on pause.”

Dilkens warned of two fallacies: that manufacturers have a surplus of funds to deploy and that the best way is to close foreign plants and build everything in the U.S.; and that even if funds were available, the U.S. is at around 4.2% unemployment.

Trump and Mark Carney set a 30-day deadline for a new trade deal. U.S. Ambassador to Canada Pete Hoekstra expressed optimism that the nations could reach an agreement. Hoekstra said there’s no reason why trade between the U.S. and Canada couldn’t be the least restrictive in the world in regards to tariffs. From a Canadian perspective, the U.S. Mexico Canada Agreement had accomplished what it was intended to do: reshore North American supply chains and increase wages in the manufacturing and auto sectors.

title: Ishiba y Trump no logran impulsar un pacto comercial por desacuerdos persistentes
content: Shigeru Ishiba, ministro de Japón, no específico un plazo concreto para la adopción de un posible pacto comercial con Washington.
resumen:
El primer ministro japonés, Shigeru Ishiba, y el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, no lograron impulsar un pacto comercial entre sus países durante su reunión en Kananaskis (Canadá), en los márgenes del G7, debido a los desacuerdos persistentes sobre sus términos.

Ishiba enfatizó en la necesidad de llegar a un acuerdo que proteja los intereses nacionales de Japón, algo que considera que aún no se ha logrado, y se abstuvo de especificar un plazo concreto para la adopción de un posible pacto comercial con Washington.

Ishiba explicó que aún hay puntos en los que están en desacuerdo, por lo que no se ha llegado a un acuerdo en términos generales.

Tokio viene pidiendo a Washington que lo exima de todas las subidas arancelarias acometidas por la Administración Trump y especialmente de la subida del 25% de los gravámenes a las importaciones estadounidenses de vehículos, que sitúan la tasa a la que están sujetos los vehículos japoneses en un 27,5%.

Donald Trump ha amenazado con elevar el arancel.

Durante el encuentro entre Ishiba y Donald Trump en Canadá, estuvieron presentes los principales negociadores en materia de aranceles de ambas partes, el ministro japonés encargado de Revitalización Económica, Ryosei Akazawa, y el secretario del Tesoro estadounidense, Scott Bessent.

Japón es uno de los países a los que Estados Unidos ha dado trato preferente en estas conversaciones, que siguen sin dar fruto tras seis rondas de encuentros ministeriales y la cumbre.

El primer ministro nipón dijo que no puede confirmar la posibilidad de extender 90 días la suspensión de lo que Washington ha llamado ‘aranceles recíprocos’, impuestos a gran parte de los países y territorios y que en el caso de Japón es del 14%.

Está previsto que la moratoria de estos gravámenes expire el 9 de julio.

Shigeru Ishiba también se negó a desvelar cuáles son las cartas sobre la mesa en las negociaciones, que según los medios locales incluirían temas de construcción naval, compras de defensa, asuntos de divisas o el coste del estacionamiento de tropas estadounidenses en Japón.

title: The S&P 500 Is Nearing a Record. Really.
content: Investors have seemingly shrugged off trade tensions and geopolitical turmoil, but the gains in the stock market don’t tell the whole story.
resumen:
The S&P 500 is less than 3 percent below its record high. The volatility that racked financial markets just two months ago has quieted.

Investors have a lot to worry about: tariffs and the growing federal deficit; immigration raids that have targeted businesses; and another major war in the Middle East, between Israel and Iran. Consumers are worried, business confidence is low, and corporate profits are expected to fall.

The S&P 500 is just 2.6 percent below its record high.

The worst anxiety whipped up in April by President Trump’s trade war has abated as the White House has delayed tariffs, offered carve-outs and hailed agreements with trading partners. Inflation data continues to show that tariffs have yet to lead to sharply higher consumer prices. The economy remains resilient.

The dip in stocks that followed Israel’s attack on Iran has been muted. On Tuesday, Mr. Trump called on Iran to unconditionally surrender. The S&P fell just 0.8 percent.

In derivatives markets, investors are still bracing for a steep drop in stocks later in the year. In the bond market, concerns over the U.S. government’s $35 trillion debt linger.

Ralph Axel, an interest-rate strategist at Bank of America, said, “On the outside it looks like a relatively normal market, but there is also very large underlying uncertainty.”

After sliding almost 19 percent from its peak in February, the S&P 500 bottomed out on April 8 and began to rally the next day when Mr. Trump delayed many of his administration’s steepest tariffs until July. The index rose almost 10 percent in one day.

Every big move higher — when the S&P 500 rose 2 percent or more — has come on a day with a significant announcement reining in tariffs. The largest gain, 3.3 percent on May 12, was the day China and the United States agreed to pause so-called reciprocal tariffs that had risen above 100 percent.

Liz Ann Sonders, chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab, said, “Aggressive ‘reciprocal tariffs’ got the market into a mess, so a pause of those tariffs got the market out of that mess.”

Every major group of companies in the index but one — health care stocks — has climbed since the low point in April, but investors have been most enthusiastic about a small number of familiar technology stocks: those of giants like Alphabet, Meta and Nvidia.

The biggest companies in the index have the biggest impact — both when it is rising and when it is falling. The growth of these tech companies has far outpaced that of other businesses.

Without the so-called Magnificent Seven stocks — Microsoft, Amazon, Tesla, Apple, Nvidia, Meta, Alphabet — the rally since the index hit its April low would be almost cut in half, according to data from Howard Silverblatt, an analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices.

A variation of the S&P 500 that’s calculated by giving equal weight to each company in the index is 4.7 percent away from its own record.

Peter Tchir, head of macro strategy at Academy Securities, said, “The benchmark doesn’t behave like we remember it. It has become so skewed to a few companies that it reflects those companies better than the average stock.”

Investors are still nervous that volatility could return as questions remain unanswered about tariffs, government spending and even the supply of workers for the economy after an immigration crackdown.

The signal being sent from the options market is that investors are girding for a potential stock slide this year.

The VIX, the index that reflects investors’ expectations of volatility in the S&P 500 over the next 30 days, spiked in April, but it has since eased.

A similar gauge of expected volatility suggests that traders don’t have as much confidence in the longer-term outlook: One way of measuring bets on a big drop in the S&P 500, called skew, is in the 96th percentile, according to data from Cboe Global Markets.

Sandy Villere, a partner and portfolio manager at Villere & Co., an investment manager, said, “I could see the second half of 2025 being much tougher for the market.”

A sustained surge in oil prices could change that. Prices did jump last week as Israel launched a large-scale attack on Iran. Those gains — about 10 percent — lifted prices only to around where they stood last year, on average. Brent Crude rose 4.4 percent on Tuesday to $76.45 after Mr. Trump’s comments on Iran.

Katie Nixon, chief investment officer of Northern Trust Wealth Management, said, “The risk is that this tailwind becomes a headwind.”

Concerns over Washington’s ability to manage its ballooning debt sent yields on government bonds soaring.

At nearly 5 percent, the yield on the 30-year Treasury is close to its highest level since October 2023.

Another measure of risk in the government bond market, one that compares the yield on U.S. treasuries with so-called risk-free rates, is close to its highest level on record, which goes back to 2020.

SOFR, or the Secured Overnight Financing Rate, is indicative of the rate at which banks, asset managers and hedge funds lend money to each other overnight.

The gap between SOFR and the 30-year Treasury yield widened to its highest level in data to date in April and has remained close to that level ever since.

Mr. Axel, the interest-rate strategist at Bank of America, said the risk of a sudden rise in long-dated Treasury yields had become a “very big” topic for the bank’s clients.

Mr. Axel said, “People do worry about that. Much more now than I have ever seen.”

title: China tiene las cartas: los minerales críticos
content: “Esta vez, las negociaciones no fueron sobre aranceles. EEUU necesita minerales críticos; China, semiconductores. Fue Trump quien pidió la reunión. Pestañeó primero”.
resumen: En la reunión entre Trump y Zelenski se acuñó una frase que capturó el desequilibrio del momento: “tú no tienes las cartas”. En el reciente acuerdo marco entre China y Estados Unidos, quedó claro quién sí las tiene: China. Las negociaciones no giraron en torno a aranceles, sino a restricciones de exportación. EEUU necesita minerales críticos; China, semiconductores. Fue Trump quien pidió la reunión. Los minerales críticos son esenciales para el desarrollo de tecnologías como AI y la descarbonización, y para la industria militar, de ahí su valor geopolítico. La Agencia Internacional de Energía muestra cómo China ha consolidado un control casi monopólico de la cadena de valor de estos minerales, combinando política industrial, inversiones estratégicas y controles de exportación. De los 20 minerales analizados, China refina 19, con una participación promedio del 70 %. En las tierras raras, su dominio es abrumador, alcanzando entre el 85 % y el 95 % del refinado global. China comprendió tempranamente que controlar el acceso a estos minerales otorga una ventaja estratégica no solo para el desarrollo tecnológico, sino como herramienta geopolítica. En 2010, impuso un embargo a Japón en el marco de una disputa territorial. Japón se vio obligado a diversificar sus fuentes, invertir en proyectos y pagar sobreprecios por seguridad de suministro. Aun así, solo logró reducir su dependencia del 90% al 60%. China concentra más del 80% de la producción mundial de baterías y del reciclaje de componentes críticos. Sus subsidios estatales han empujado los precios a niveles que dificultan la entrada de nuevos actores. Cuando empresas extranjeras intentan competir, China responde inundando el mercado, bajando los precios hasta hacer inviable cualquier competencia. El informe de la IEA dice que la diversificación no ocurrirá de forma automática, ni puede dejarse al arbitrio de las fuerzas del mercado. En este escenario, las decisiones de inversión no responden criterios económicos, sino al interés estratégico de los Estados. Chile tiene buenas cartas para posicionarse como un actor relevante en la gobernanza global de estos recursos.

title: Carney y Trump fijan un plazo de 30 días para alcanzar un acuerdo arancelario
content: El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, y el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, han fijado este lunes un plazo máximo de 30 días para alcanzar algún tipo de acuerdo comercial y, en ...
resumen: El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, y el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, han fijado este lunes un plazo máximo de 30 días para alcanzar algún tipo de acuerdo comercial y, en particular, en materia de aranceles. Carney y Trump han establecido este plazo durante un encuentro que ambos han mantenido este lunes al margen de la cumbre de países del G7 que está teniendo lugar en la localidad canadiense de Kananaskis, y en el que han coincidido en la necesidad de acelerar las conversaciones con el objetivo de llegar a un pacto en materia comercial durante el próximo mes. Trump aseguró horas antes que los dos países "pueden resolver algo" respecto a sus tensiones comerciales y, si bien afirmó ser un "amante de los aranceles", también reconoció que Carney "tiene una idea más compleja, pero sigue siendo muy buena". Trump elevara al 50 por ciento el impuesto a las importaciones de acero y aluminio. También los vehículos fabricados en el extranjero tienen nuevos aranceles, además del gravamen del 25 por ciento a los productos de Canadá y México, países con los que Estados Unidos mantiene un acuerdo comercial.

title: Trump abandona la cumbre del G7 por conflicto en Medio Oriente y suspende reunión con Sheinbaum
content: Trump abandona la cumbre del G7 por conflicto Israel-Irán y cancela su reunión con Sheinbaum; crecen tensiones bilaterales y globales.
resumen: La escalada bélica entre Israel e Irán obligó al presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, a regresar a Washington de forma anticipada, interrumpiendo la Cumbre del Grupo de los Siete (G7) en Kananaskis, Canadá. Trump urgió a evacuar Teherán y advirtió que el tiempo se agota para que Irán detenga su programa nuclear. Decidió cancelar varias reuniones programadas, incluyendo la que sostendría con la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum. La reunión Sheinbaum-Trump, postergada por la crisis, era clave ante las crecientes tensiones migratorias y comerciales. Sheinbaum había arribado a Calgary tras más de diez horas de vuelo comercial. La visita de Sheinbaum “continúa con su participación como jefa de Estado invitada a la Cumbre del G7”. Ambos mandatarios abordarían temas sensibles: los recientes aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos, las detenciones de mexicanos en redadas migratorias y las acusaciones del gobierno estadounidense contra Sheinbaum por presuntamente incitar protestas en Los Ángeles. El secretario de Seguridad, Omar García Harfuch, también asistiría al encuentro. Trump insistió en que Irán debe detener su programa nuclear “antes de que sea demasiado tarde”. El presidente francés, Emmanuel Macron, reveló que Trump propuso un alto el fuego entre Teherán y Tel Aviv. La escalada del conflicto comenzó cuatro días antes, cuando Israel inició una campaña de bombardeos sobre Irán. Karoline Leavitt, secretaria de prensa, justificó la salida del mandatario. Trump declaró en Canadá que su gobierno redoblará redadas, especialmente en ciudades santuario como Los Ángeles, Nueva York y Chicago. El primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, tuvo que intervenir y terminar la conferencia. Trump ha impuesto aranceles del 50% sobre acero y aluminio, y del 25% a los automóviles. Se esperaba que la reunión con Sheinbaum sirviera para discutir estos puntos y negociar plazos antes del 9 de julio. Desde el inicio del segundo mandato de Trump, más de 56 mil mexicanos han sido repatriados. De ellos, 12 mil llegaron por vía aérea a México, y más de 13 mil han sido trasladados por el INM a sus estados de origen. En las recientes redadas en Los Ángeles, las autoridades mexicanas confirmaron la detención de 61 personas. Se reportó la muerte de un mexicano de 45 años bajo custodia del ICE. Sheinbaum dijo que “siempre vamos a buscar el respeto a los derechos humanos de los mexicanos en el exterior”. Sheinbaum mantendrá el resto de sus actividades en Canadá, incluyendo: Reunión trilateral con la Comisión y el Consejo Europeo, encuentro bilateral con Narendra Modi, primer ministro de India, participación en la plenaria del G7 sobre paz, seguridad y cooperación, reunión con el canciller alemán Friedrich Merz, y encuentro bilateral con Mark Carney, primer ministro canadiense. Esta es la tercera gira internacional de Sheinbaum. Sheinbaum se mostró comprensiva ante la cancelación. Trump dejó claro que no hay margen para distracciones. Mark Carney, anfitrión de la cumbre, agradeció la presencia del mandatario estadounidense y dijo comprender su decisión. La oferta de Trump para un alto el fuego entre Irán e Israel podría marcar un giro.

title: Las remesas recibidas por República Dominicana entre enero y mayo aumentaron un 11,9 %
content: Santo Domingo, 17 jun (EFE).- Las remesas recibidas por la República Dominicana entre enero y mayo de este año alcanzaron los 4.903 millones de dólares, un aumento del 11,9 % en comparación con el mis ...
resumen:
Las remesas recibidas por la República Dominicana entre enero y mayo aumentaron un 11,9 %.

Las remesas recibidas por la República Dominicana entre enero y mayo de este año alcanzaron los 4.903 millones de dólares, un aumento del 11,9 % en comparación con el mismo período del año anterior.

En mayo se registró un valor de remesas de 985,5 millones de dólares, lo que representa un crecimiento del 11,1 % respecto al mismo mes de 2024.

El 83,1 % de las remesas enviadas en mayo llegó desde Estados Unidos.

España aportó un 5,9 % del total.

La participación desde Haití fue del 1,4 %.

Las aportaciones de Italia y Suiza, cada una, supusieron el 1,1 % de los flujos recibidos.

title: Trump has redefined U.S. tariff strategy. Here’s what Utahns have to say about it
content: A new poll reveals Utah voters’ feelings about the president’s trade policies, how they're being personally impacted and what retailers should share about tariff-related price changes.
resumen:
A new Deseret News/Hinckley Institute of Politics statewide survey reveals how Utahns are feeling about Trump’s approach to international trade policy.

Trump has directed a series of incremental increases in U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods, as well as imports from other countries, since he took office.

In an online poll conducted May 8-15 of 805 registered Utah voters, Harris X pollsters asked participants, “Do you support or oppose the Trump Administration’s tariff program?”

Overall, Utah voters’ sentiments were close to split with 50% of respondents weighing-in as somewhat or strongly in support of Trump’s tariff plans while 44% somewhat or strongly opposed the president’s trade policies. Of those in the support group, 69% were self-identified Republicans and 19% Democrats. In the opposition category, 25% were Republicans and 81% Democrats.

When asked “Which comes closest to your views of the Trump administration’s tariff policies?” and given three response options, 19% of respondents aligned with “It’s the right idea but has been executed badly,” 53% chose “It’s the right idea but requires more time to work,” and 28% opted for “It’s the wrong idea regardless of execution and time required.” The partisan divide for the first response was about even but in the “right idea, executed badly” group, 69% of poll participants were Republicans and 22% Democrats. Among the “wrong idea, regardless” respondents, 12% were Republicans and 64% Democrats.

When surveyors asked “Have the administration’s tariff policies so far helped you, hurt you or has it had no impact?” 16% said tariffs have been a help, 36% said they have been hurt by Trump tariff policy and a plurality of poll participants, 48%, said they believe the tariff changes have had no impact on their lives.

Testing Utah voters’ feelings about tariff line items, HarrisX asked poll participants whether they supported or opposed the practice. An easy majority of respondents, 56%, said they somewhat or strongly support the practice while 30% somewhat or strongly oppose it and 14% said they weren’t sure.

title: U.S. Revokes Visa of Panama’s Former President Who Criticized Trump Deal
content: Two politicians who spoke out against recent accords between the United States and Panama lost their permission to travel to the United States.
resumen: The U.S. State Department revoked the travel visas of Martín Torrijos, former president of Panama from 2004 to 2009, and Ricardo Lombana, a lawyer who came in second in Panama’s presidential election last year. Torrijos announced at a news conference on Monday that he had been notified by the U.S. government that his visa had been canceled. Lombana said he received word in an email on Monday that his visa had also been yanked. The visa revocations came after months of tensions between Panama and Mr. Trump. Panama’s current president, José Raúl Mulino, took measures that his critics called concessions to Mr. Trump, including agreeing to accept non-Panamanian migrants deported from the United States and signing an agreement that would allow more U.S. troops on three former U.S. bases in Panama. The United States said Mr. Mulino had also agreed to waive the fees American warships pay to transit the canal — a deal Mr. Mulino denied making, but later agreed to. Torrijos and Lombana joined forces in April to speak out after the U.S. defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, visited Panama. They joined a group of about 1,500 people who signed an open letter calling the deals “harmful to national sovereignty.” The U.S. State Department declined to explain why the two politicians’ travel visas were revoked. Carlos Ruiz-Hernández, a former deputy foreign minister of Panama who helped negotiate the agreements, said the opposition politicians exaggerated the contents of the accords. Three other former Panamanian presidents have had their visas revoked for corruption, including Juan Carlos Varela, Ricardo Martinelli and Ernesto Pérez Balladares.

title: Trump Renews Embrace of Putin Amid Rift With Allies
content: President Trump opened his remarks at the Group of 7 gathering of industrialized nations by criticizing the decision to expel Russia from the bloc after Moscow’s 2014 “annexation” of Crimea.
resumen:
During Monday’s meeting in Canada of the leaders of the Group of 7 industrialized nations, President Trump appeared to focus on President Vladimir Putin of Russia.

Mr. Trump told reporters that the G7 used to be the G8, referring to the group’s decision to eject Russia in 2014 after it attacked Ukraine and “annexed” Crimea. He blamed former President Barack Obama and former Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada for kicking Russia out, and argued that its inclusion in the group would have averted the war in Ukraine. Mr. Trump said, “I would say that was a mistake, because I think you wouldn’t have a war right now.”

When he attended the summit in Canada in 2018, he called for Russia to be readmitted to the alliance. He left the summit early, telling reporters on his way out: “They should let Russia come back in. Because we should have Russia at the negotiating table.”

Mr. Trump’s remarks came one day before he was supposed to meet in Canada with Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky. The White House announced on Monday that Mr. Trump would leave the summit early and return to Washington to deal with the war between Israel and Iran. In a recent interview, Mr. Trump said he was open to having Mr. Putin serve as a mediator in the Middle East conflict.

Mr. Trump returned to the summit three years after Russia launched an unprovoked invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

A White House official said Mr. Trump had long held that view and would share his opinion even if he were meeting with global leaders who feel differently.

Mr. Trump repeated a claim he made in 2018, that the Group of 7 needed Mr. Putin to help solve some of the world’s problems. Mr. Trump said, “You spend so much time talking about Russia, and he’s no longer at the table.”

John Bolton, Mr. Trump’s former national security adviser, said Mr. Trump’s multiple calls for Russia to rejoin the alliance indicated his lack of knowledge about the history of the bloc.

Mr. Trump said, “Putin speaks to me; he doesn’t speak to anybody else, because he was very insulted when he got thrown out at the G8, as I would be, as you would be, as anybody would be.”

Mr. Trump has spoken with Mr. Putin regularly, as recently as Saturday, when he said that the Russian leader had called him to wish him a “Happy Birthday” and spent more time discussing the Iranian-Israeli conflict than the war he started.

Daniel M. Price said, “Our G7 partners are likely to conclude that Trump may be more interested in rehabilitating Putin rather than joining the consensus supporting Ukraine.”

Mr. Trump has claimed he could end the war in one day. He has also acknowledged that Mr. Putin may be taking advantage of him by dragging out the war.

Mr. Trump has repeatedly threatened tariffs against Russia, though he has yet to follow through.

Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain, along with other European leaders, was expected to announce another sanctions package against Russia.

Mr. Starmer said in a statement that he wanted to “work with all of our G7 partners to squeeze Russia’s energy revenues and reduce the funds they are able to pour into their illegal war.”

Mr. Trump downplayed the measure, saying, “Well, Europe is saying that, but they haven’t done it yet. Let’s see them do it first.”

Mr. Trump said he was still waiting to see if a cease-fire deal could be made, adding that sanctions would also be costly for the United States.

Mr. Trump has also indicated that he wants to all but wash his hands of the war in Ukraine.

Josh Lipsky said, “To make that particular point I think cuts to the core of the recent most successful actions the G7 has taken. It puts the summit in a G6 plus one dynamic right off the bat.”

title: Carney saca a Trump un mes para negociar un acuerdo arancelario, antes de adelantar regreso a EU
content: El encuentro bilateral, último antes de que abandonara cumbre del G7, sin reunirse este martes en Canadá con Sheinbaum ...
resumen: El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, y el primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, acordaron llegar a un acuerdo comercial en un plazo de 30 días tras mantener una reunión bilateral antes del comienzo de la Cumbre del G7. Trump se regresa este mismo lunes a Washington, sin reunirse con la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum. Durante su reunión “abordaron las presiones comerciales inmediatas y las prioridades para los trabajadores y las empresas de ambos países”. Trump y Carney también hablaron sobre las negociaciones que los dos países mantienen desde hace semanas para llegar a un nuevo acuerdo arancelario. Ambos líderes acordaron que haya negociaciones con el objetivo de alcanzar un acuerdo en los próximos 30 días. Además, durante el encuentro trataron los minerales críticos, el tráfico de armas y drogas, los estupefacientes ilegales y la seguridad fronteriza junto con posibles áreas de cooperación en materia de defensa.

title: Trump and Starmer Agree to Implement Parts of Trade Deal on Cars, Steel and Planes
content: The leaders of Britain and the United States announced a deal last month, but it had not been clear when their agreement would go into effect. Britain hailed the announcement as “a huge win.” ...
resumen:
President Trump and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain said on Monday that they had finalized their trade agreement to lower tariffs on British cars, steel and aluminum, and aerospace equipment.

In an executive order issued moments after the two leaders made the announcement at the Group of 7 summit in Canada, Mr. Trump lowered the U.S. tariff on British cars to 10 percent, from 25 percent, and ordered that the United States let a certain amount of British steel and aluminum into the U.S. tariff-free.

The order also lowers tariffs on some airplane parts.

Mr. Trump told reporters, “We just signed it and it’s done.” He praised Mr. Starmer’s negotiating skills.

Mr. Starmer called the agreement “really important” and added, “This is a very good day.”

The White House said that the Commerce Department will still need to set a quota for the volume of British steel that can enter the country tariff-free under the agreement the countries reached in May. Mr. Trump had raised tariffs on all foreign steel products to 50 percent earlier this month.

When an agreement between Mr. Trump and Mr. Starmer was first announced in May, it was short on details and left many topics to be negotiated. It did say that Britain would drop its tariffs on U.S. beef, ethanol, sports equipment and other products, and buy $10 billion of Boeing airplanes, while the United States said it would pare back tariffs on cars and steel but leave a 10 percent levy in place for all other British exports.

Mr. Starmer’s office said in a statement that the agreement “will save hundreds of millions annually for plane and carmakers with lowered tariffs and protect tens of thousands of jobs across both sectors.” The statement added, “This deal is a huge win for the U.K.’s world-class aerospace sector currently facing additional 10 percent tariffs, helping make companies such as Rolls-Royce more competitive and allowing them to continue to be at the cutting edge of innovation.”

The announcement still leaves uncertainty over other topics that negotiators from the countries continue to discuss. That includes the U.S. response to digital service taxes levied by the U.K. government against American tech firms, as well as other tariffs Mr. Trump expects to impose on products like pharmaceuticals.

Mr. Trump hinted that he might make more trade announcements while he is at the summit Monday and Tuesday.

The president announced tariffs on dozens of countries in early April, then paused those taxes for 90 days to allow for trade negotiations. His advisers have been holding trade talks with 18 governments that hope to reach deals before the tariffs snap back into effect July 8.

The G7 meetings in Canada provide an opportunity for several of America’s closest trading partners to push for a trade truce. Earlier on Monday, Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada and Mr. Trump met behind closed doors. In a readout of the meeting provided by Mr. Carney’s office, the two leaders agreed to try and reach a negotiated trade deal within the next 30 days. Mr. Trump also sat down with the European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, on Monday at her request, the White House said.

In a social media post Monday, Ms. von der Leyen said that the summit was “an opportunity for good and deep talks between partners" and that she and Mr. Trump had instructed their teams to “accelerate their work to strike a good and fair deal” on trade.

title: Japón afirma que no hubo avances sobre aranceles tras reunión entre Ishiba y Trump
content: TOKIO, 17 jun (Xinhua) -- El primer ministro japonés, Shigeru Ishiba, afirmó que no se lograron avances significativos en las negociaciones arancelarias con el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Tru ...
resumen: TOKIO, 17 jun (Xinhua) -- El primer ministro japonés, Shigeru Ishiba, afirmó que no se lograron avances significativos en las negociaciones arancelarias con el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, durante su encuentro celebrado el lunes en Canadá en el marco de la cumbre del Grupo de los Siete (G7). Tras la reunión, Ishiba declaró a la prensa que persisten diferencias de enfoque entre ambos países y que no se ha alcanzado un acuerdo integral, según reportó hoy martes el periódico Nikkei. Ishiba subrayó que ambas naciones realizaron esfuerzos serios durante las conversaciones y acordaron dar instrucciones a sus respectivos ministros para que continúen las negociaciones. No obstante, se abstuvo de especificar un plazo concreto para la posible conclusión de un acuerdo. Actualmente, Japón enfrenta un arancel del 25 por ciento impuesto por Estados Unidos sobre automóviles y autopartes, y otro del 50 por ciento sobre el acero y el aluminio. A pesar de las anteriores rondas de negociaciones a nivel ministerial, los avances han sido escasos.

title: Focus: China pharma projects disrupted by Sino-US tensions
content: Drug research and development firms in China including WuXi AppTec and WuXi Biologics are changing project plans, stockpiling supplies and discussing testing locally, said sources with knowledge of ...
resumen:
Drug research and development firms in China including WuXi AppTec (603259.SS) and WuXi Biologics (2269.HK) are changing project plans, stockpiling supplies and discussing testing locally, as they seek to mitigate the impact of U.S.-China trade tensions.

China's pharmaceutical research and manufacturing sector serves global drug giants such as Pfizer (PFE.N) and AstraZeneca (AZN.L).

Fears of delay in access to U.S. supply chains and raised import tariffs are spurring biotech and pharmaceutical companies to avoid, pause or consider delaying the start of projects, according to three sources.

They are also discussing testing U.S. clinical samples in the U.S., instead of sending them to China for further research, a move that could increase costs, and requesting additional supplies for backup, three other sources said.

The six sources who spoke to Reuters are director or executive-level employees involved in various aspects of the industry in China including research and development, manufacturing and supply chains.

In 2024, the U.S. exported diagnostic and laboratory reagents to China valued at about $1.4 billion and prepared culture media for the development or maintenance of microorganisms worth about $125 million, U.N. Comtrade data showed.

Some U.S.-made goods including diagnostic reagents from Germany's Siemens Healthineers (SHLG.DE) were exempted from raised Chinese tariffs, that company said in May.

China raised its tariffs on U.S. imports to as much as 125% though it has since reduced that to 10% while it works out a more permanent trade deal.

WuXi AppTec and a Chinese biotechnology firm that was its research client agreed in May to switch U.S.-made reagents they had been using for a Hepatitis B virus pre-clinical research project into non-U.S. versions due partly to concerns about higher costs from tariffs, a source at the client company said.

The project had been temporarily paused during the discussions, which began prior to May, the source said.

Since April, at least 17 Chinese biotech and pharmaceutical clients have contacted Chinese cell culture media manufacturer JS Biosciences asking it to keep locally-made backup raw materials for production because they were concerned about cost increases or the inability to access foreign supplies, the firm's CEO Luo Shun said.

Another Chinese drug research and development firm decided not to provide a quotation to a foreign pharmaceutical company interested in hiring it for protein drug manufacturing, due to delays in obtaining necessary U.S.-made culture medium from a U.S. subsidiary of Japan's Fujifilm (4901.T), a source at the Chinese firm said.

After China announced a large rise in tariffs for U.S. imports in April, WuXi Biologics (2269.HK) placed a bigger-than-normal order for reagents made in the U.S. with a supplier because it was not sure how long that policy action would continue, said a source at the supplier.

Concerns about the potential for U.S. export restrictions led China's Innovent Biologics (1801.HK) and multinational BeOne Medicines (688235.SS) to discuss with Massachusetts-headquartered Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO.N) the prospect of not sending U.S. clinical samples to China, said a source at the U.S. company.

title: Are Trump’s tariffs really making America Great Again?
content: Trump’s tariffs are not delivering in the way he promised. New data reveals rising costs, stalling investment, and mounting risks for inflation and global growth.
resumen:
The average US tariff rate is now 7.0%, the highest since 1969.

Trump’s tariffs are expected to generate $686 billion in revenue for the government over the next decade.

Real GDP growth has already been trimmed by 0.18 percentage points for 2025.

The long-run GDP hit is projected at 0.06% annually, which is equivalent to $20 billion.

American households are projected to lose $950 in annual purchasing power, and job losses are expected to reach 127,000 this year.

JPMorgan estimates the new tariffs will add $400 billion per year to import costs.

CPI could rise to 3.0% or even 3.5% by the end of Q3.

President Trump has claimed his economic agenda has unleashed more than $12 trillion in business investment, but the real number is likely less than 1% of that.

The White House’s official list of announced investments totals about $5.3 trillion, but a Goldman Sachs analysis found that only $134 billion of that is new.

Once researchers accounted for projects that were already planned, not US-specific, or unlikely to materialize, the number dropped to as low as $30 billion.

Manufacturing output is slightly negative overall.

Auto prices have jumped 8.4% in the short term, or about $2,400 more per new vehicle.

The government is projected to collect $686 billion in additional tariff revenue over the next decade.

$101 billion in lost tax revenue is estimated due to slower economic growth caused by the tariffs.

The US will bear the brunt in the short term, with the clearest supply shock in decades.

Europe is already feeling second-hand pressure.

China is arguably more agile in its response.

The Federal Reserve now faces a near-impossible task: stimulate growth without stoking inflation.

The Fed’s rate decision is on the 18th of June.

title: White House executive order addresses key elements of the U.S.-U.K. trade deal
content: When this deal was initially announced in May, the U.S. Department of Commerce labeled it a “historic trade deal-providing unprecedented access to the U.K. markets while bolstering U.S. national ...
resumen: Following the initial announcement of a trade deal between the United States and United Kingdom on May 8, an executive order issued by the White House yesterday moved forward in implementing various components of the deal. The U.S. Department of Commerce labeled it a “historic trade deal-providing unprecedented access to the U.K. markets while bolstering U.S. national security.” The trade deal will usher in a golden age of new opportunity for U.S. exporters, establishing a long-sought level playing field for American producers, with yesterday’s executive order expands U.S. market access, with a focus on strengthening national security and economic alliances with the U.K. The deal includes billions of dollars of increased market access for American exports, especially for beef, ethanol, and certain other American agricultural exports. In addition, the United Kingdom will reduce or eliminate numerous non-tariff barriers that unfairly discriminate against American products, hurt the United States’ manufacturing base, and threaten the national security of the United States. Key components of this deal outlined in the executive order include: a tariff-rate quota (TRQ) of 100,000 U.K.-made automobiles is established and subject to a reduced 10% total tariff (instead of the standard 25%), quotas exceeding this limit will still face full tariffs, and certain automotive parts from the U.K. will also qualify for the reduced 10% tariff if used in U.K.-made vehicles; U.K. aerospace products covered under the WTO’s Civil Aircraft Agreement will no longer face tariffs imposed under previous executive actions and proclamations; the U.S. will design future TRQs for U.K. steel and aluminum products (and derivatives), provided the U.K. meets security and ownership standards outlined in the deal, and products beyond these quotas will still face existing tariffs; the U.S. and U.K. will work toward preferential treatment for U.K. pharmaceuticals and ingredients, contingent on a national security investigation and compliance with supply chain standards; and both countries commit to structured negotiation to address U.S. national security concerns in sectors subject to future trade investigations, and a shared effort will also be made to strengthen aerospace and aircraft manufacturing supply chains with tariff-free bilateral trade. The executive order also stated it allows for necessary regulatory updates and rules by the Secretary of Commerce in coordination with other agencies and clarifies that the order doesn't create enforceable legal rights and is subject to budget and legal constraints. A White House fact sheet stated that U.S. goods trade was an estimated $148 billion in 2024. The U.K. average applied agricultural tariff is 9.2%, with the U.S. average applied agricultural tariff, prior to April 2, was 5%. The U.K. maintains certain tariff and non-tariff barriers that restrict market access and create an unfair playing field for American workers and businesses. The U.K. imposes tariffs that can exceed 125% on meat, poultry, and dairy products on top of maintaining non-science-based standards that adversely affect U.S. exports.

title: Exportaciones chinas se dispararon en marzo ante aranceles de Trump
content: Países analizan tomar medidas para evitar que su industria local se vea afectada por ingreso de productos del gigante asiático.
resumen:
Las exportaciones de China se dispararon un 12,4% en marzo de 2025 en comparación con el mismo mes del año anterior, marcando su mayor crecimiento desde octubre de 2024. Este repunte se atribuye en gran medida a un adelantamiento estratégico de envíos por parte de las empresas, anticipándose a los nuevos aranceles impuestos por el gobierno de Donald Trump.

La industria manufacturera china aprovechó el primer trimestre del año para maximizar sus exportaciones antes de la entrada en vigor de los nuevos gravámenes, especialmente en sectores como la electrónica y los productos químicos. Estados Unidos elevó los aranceles sobre bienes clave, incluyendo semiconductores y baterías, como parte de una estrategia para reducir la dependencia de las importaciones chinas.

Este incremento generó un superávit comercial mensual de US$ 102,600 millones. Los economistas advierten que este impulso podría ser temporal. La demanda global sigue mostrando signos de debilidad, y las crecientes fricciones comerciales entre las dos mayores economías del mundo podrían afectar la estabilidad del comercio internacional en los próximos meses.

El incremento de las exportaciones chinas ha generado efectos mixtos en los mercados emergentes y en la Unión Europea. La UE evalúa posibles medidas para contrarrestar el exceso de productos chinos en su mercado.

El sector energético se mantiene atento al impacto de la política comercial en el consumo de petróleo y gas natural, dado que cualquier disminución en la producción industrial china podría afectar la demanda global.

China se ha enfocado en fortalecer lazos comerciales con diversos países, convirtiéndose incluso en su principal socio comercial. Fábricas del gigante asiático envían juguetes, automóviles y zapatos de forma abundante.

En lo que va del año China tiene un superávit comercial con el mundo de casi US$ 500,000 millones, más del 40% con respecto del mismo periodo del año anterior.

Leah Fahy, economista especializada en China en Capital Economics, dijo que es prácticamente imposible detener los cambios en los flujos.

La producción masiva se debería principalmente al colapso inmobiliario que sufrió el país asiático en 2021, cuando las políticas restrictivas del gobierno limitaron el acceso a financiamiento para los desarrolladores altamente endeudados. Empresas como Evergrande y Country Garden enfrentaron dificultades financieras, lo que provocó una caída en los precios de la vivienda y una desaceleración en la construcción.

Las autoridades chinas actuaron rápidamente para redirigir préstamos de bajo costo, antes destinados a desarrolladores inmobiliarios, hacia exportadores y fabricantes. Esto ayudó a equilibrar el impacto del colapso del sector de la construcción, que en su mejor momento representaba aproximadamente un tercio del crecimiento económico.

Tommy Wu, economista de Commerzbank, dijo que las políticas gubernamentales contribuyen a que se tenga este problema hoy en día.

En 2015, China emprendió una política industrial para fabricar bienes de mayor valor que requieren mano de obra cualificada, denominada "Hecho en China 2025". Estados Unidos y países europeos aumentaron los aranceles sobre los automóviles eléctricos, paneles solares y otros productos de alta tecnología.

Priyanka Kishore, economista de Singapur, señaló que usualmente las economías que vuelven más desarrolladas se alejan de la manufactura de gama baja, algo que el país asiático no ha dejado de hacer.

En Alemania, las importaciones de productos chinos aumentaron un 20 % el mes pasado en comparación con el mismo período del año anterior, lo que ha generado preocupación entre las empresas, especialmente en el sector automotriz.

China ha incrementado su producción de vehículos eléctricos en un 45 % este año, a pesar de la feroz competencia interna y la caída de la demanda en su mercado nacional. Las exportaciones de estos automóviles han crecido aún más, con un aumento del 64,6 %, según la Asociación China de Fabricantes de Automóviles.

En Indonesia, se ha visto el cierre de fábricas textiles que no pueden competir con la ropa más barata de China. Entre 2023 y 2024, unas 250.000 personas perdieron sus empleos en el sector, según Redma Gita Wirawasta, presidenta de la Asociación Indonesia de Productores de Hilados y Fibras.

Tailandia ha sufrido el cierre de fábricas de autopartes debido a la invasión de vehículos eléctricos chinos en el mercado. Brasil enfrenta una crisis en su industria automotriz, lo que ha llevado a los fabricantes nacionales a solicitar al gobierno que inicie una investigación antidumping contra los automóviles chinos.

Los países se han visto envueltos en una encrucijada. Por un lado, temen tomar una postura proteccionista y elevar aranceles, lo que podría generar una medida de respuesta por parte de China, con quien tienen interdependencia económica.

Sonal Varma, economista jefe para Asia, con excepción de Japón, de Nomura, el banco japonés, afirmó que las cadenas de suministro se están bifurcando según criterios geopolíticos.

title: ONU aclara que en Bolivia no existe riesgo de hambruna y valora esfuerzos gubernamentales
content: La Paz, 17 jun (EFE).- La Organización de Naciones Unidas (ONU) afirmó este martes que Bolivia no está en riesgo de "hambruna" y que dicho término no figura en el reciente informe del Programa Mundial ...
resumen:
La Organización de Naciones Unidas (ONU) afirmó que Bolivia no está en riesgo de «hambruna» y que dicho término no figura en el reciente informe del Programa Mundial de Alimentos (PMA).
La coordinadora residente de la ONU en Bolivia, Anna Pont, sostuvo una reunión con autoridades del Gobierno boliviano en la Cancillería sobre el informe del organismo titulado ‘Puntos críticos sobre el hambre: Alertas tempranas sobre la inseguridad alimentaria aguda. Perspectiva de junio a octubre de 2025’.
Pont leyó un comunicado en el que se señala que el informe «no menciona ni alerta sobre una situación de hambruna en Bolivia».
El informe «identifica 13 países donde la situación del hambre está empeorando, incluyendo cinco con riesgo inmediato de hambruna: Sudán, Palestina, Sudán del Sur, Haití y Mali», y que Bolivia «no figura entre los 13 países de mayor preocupación».
El ministro de Planificación de Bolivia, Sergio Cusicanqui, quien participó en el encuentro, señaló que se reafirma el compromiso de seguir trabajando con la vocación productiva que tiene el Gobierno nacional y que se continuará impulsando el incremento de la producción, especialmente agrícola, y asegurar el abastecimiento de alimentos para toda la población boliviana.
La directora regional para América Latina y el Caribe del PMA, Lola Castro, declaró que en Bolivia se observa un deterioro de la seguridad alimentaria a causa de la elevada inflación, así como de la escasez de divisas y combustibles.
Las estadísticas del PMA, actualizadas a octubre de 2024, establecieron que unos 2,2 millones de personas —el 19 % de la población boliviana— se encontraban en situación de inseguridad alimentaria aguda.
Bolivia enfrenta escasez de divisas desde principios de 2023 y, desde 2024, son frecuentes las irregularidades en el abastecimiento de gasolina y diésel, combustibles subvencionados por el Estado.
El país cerró 2024 con una inflación del 9,97 %, la más alta desde 2008, mientras que la inflación acumulada en los cinco primeros meses de este año alcanzó el 9,8 %.
